p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 37th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament:
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP Ms Alison Byrnes MP Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP Ms Tracey Roberts MP Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
private session in the 47th Parliament on
6 November 2024, 20 November 2024, 27 November 2024, 22 January 2025 and 5 February 2025.

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 87 petitions:
Parent Visas

Thousands of families across Australia are suffering due to excessively long wait times for parental visas. These delays leave families fragmented, preventing them from sharing in important life events and providing essential support during challenging times. The emotional toll of prolonged separation is immense, causing anxiety and distress for both parents and children. This situation is not just an inconvenience; it undermines the fundamental values of family unity and support that are central to Australian culture. Every family deserves the right to be together, and it is unacceptable for loving families to endure such unnecessary hardship due to bureaucratic delays.

We therefore ask the House to take immediate action to reform the parental visa application process. Specifically, we urge the government to prioritize the processing times for parental visas. By streamlining these processes, families can be reunited more quickly, allowing them to support one another and contribute positively to Australian society. It is crucial to act swiftly to prevent further pain and suffering caused by unnecessary separation due to bureaucratic delays. Together, we can advocate for a more humane and efficient immigration system that prioritizes family reunification, ensuring that every family has the opportunity to thrive together in Australia.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6708)
Jervis Bay Territory: Christians Minde

The Sussex Inlet Chamber of Commerce representing the community of Sussex Inlet and original owners the Ellmoos family have had concerns for over 10 years about the lack of maintenance and repair not completed by the previous lessees. The oversight by the Australian government has been neglectful in failing to implement the Historic Heritage Management Plan for Christians Minde Settlement prepared by Godden Mackay Logan in 2015. This neglect has resulted in many high level risks in preservation of the structures and people who access the site.
We therefore ask the House to h Government to act to:
Endorse and adopt the Historic Heritage Management Plan for Christians Minde Settlement prepared by Godden Mackay Logan in 2015.
Apply the principles, guidelines and recommendations in the 2015 Historic Heritage Management Plan for Christians Minde.
Review the Indigenous Heritage Management report for the Christian's Minde Settlement, circa 2015-16 including cultural landscape and cultural heritage.

Review the terms of the lease with regards to heritage protection, both built heritage and Aboriginal cultural heritage, and any breaches by the Lessee or Government under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (EPBC) 1999
Improve the heritage protection for the site—and all sites in the JBT listed on the Commonwealth Heritage List.
Undertake urgent maintenance and repairs to the built heritage at Christians Minde Settlement.
Ensure accurate reporting about the condition of the property by the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water (DCCEW) in the next EPBC Act 1999 report, which was due in 2023.
from 549 citizens (Petition No. EN6711)
Telecommunications

The government should adopt the Rich Communication Services (RCS) messaging standard as a national priority to enhance digital communication. RCS offers a secure, interoperable platform that modernises traditional SMS by enabling features like end-to-end encryption, high-quality multimedia sharing, group chats, and real-time updates all without the need for third-party apps. Implementing RCS would promote competition for the consumer market, reduce dependency on foreign messaging platforms, and ensure that critical communication infrastructure meets the needs of modern society in a secure and accessible manner. We believe this is a necessary step to foster innovation and strengthen the nation's digital ecosystem.

We therefore ask the House to to take immediate action to adopt the Rich Communication Services (RCS) messaging standard across all mobile networks and devices such as iPhone's and Android Phones within the country. This includes mandating its implementation as the default messaging protocol to replace outdated SMS technology, ensuring interoperability among service providers, and providing the necessary regulatory framework to protect consumer privacy and data security. By doing so, the government would foster a more secure, reliable, and feature-rich communication infrastructure that meets the demands of modern digital communication while promoting fair competition and innovation in the telecom sector.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6713)
Lead Manufacturing Industry

Australia is the world's largest lead (ore/concentrate) exporter—often to countries with lax controls on shipping, smelting, refining, manufacturing and recycling, allowing the continuing flow of Australian lead into cheap products that're banned here (like lead paint, toxic Ayurvedic medicines/spices/cosmetics); and into footpath/backyard/kitchen recycling (including by children). The annual global cost of lead exposure is US$6 trillion (2019)—7% of global GDP. A moratorium on all new 'lead mines' (where lead is the highest tonnage metal) especially 'greenfield' projects like Bowdens, will prevent land and water contamination of agricultural/grazing land/indigenous sites and reduce water, fossil-fuel and infrastructure requirements. 'Mining' existing lead from the built environment; and incentivising householders to replace lead with non-lead flashing, especially on rainwater collection roof areas; and industry to collect, transport and recycle lead radiation shielding, weights, pewter, brass, solder, spent ammunition along with used lead acid batteries; and to manufacture new lead acid batteries from 100% recycled lead; and 'export' lead ingots with the technology/policy to assist other countries to achieve lead circularity, will obviate the need for newly-mined lead, create a smarter world (more capable of solving the climate crisis), and create a lead-safe and climate-safe planet for future generations.

We therefore ask the House to create lead circularity: commit to a moratorium on all new mine projects where lead is the major mine product by weight, and incentivize 'mining' the built environment and waste-streams for lead; manufacturing new lead acid batteries from 100% recycled-lead; and exporting lead ingots, and lead-safety technologies/knowledge.
from 95 citizens (Petition No. EN6714)
Freedom of Speech

The human right of having individual liberties, should be safeguarded. As per articles 19, 21 and 22 of the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Then High Court of Australia has determined the implied right to "free speech". Governments should be prevented from making laws in this sphere. No matter the intention of the law, it can be used against the citizens in the future if a parliament that doesn't believe in freedom of speech is elected. People can still take action for defamation/liblel under common law. People that cause harm with their speech can still be prosecuted under criminal law if their speech causes fear or harm. People should suffer the consequences of the actions that they choose to take, as they always have been.

We therefore ask the House to initialise a referendum to enshrine Freedom of Speech in the Australian Constitution, and enshrine the existing civil law, that has existed as a democratic right, since time immemorial, as a human right.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN6715)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
The ABC is any conservative and totally biased towards the progressive side of politics.
We therefore ask the House to have an independent investigation and if found to be biased, force it to be unbiased or defund it.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6716)
Medicare: Allied Health

Bowen Therapy is a distinctive Australian, neuromuscular, soft-tissue remedial technique involving gentle rolling moves on specific anatomical locations. This technique is not commonly found in other modalities.

Prior to the removal of health fund status, Bowen Therapy was a thriving industry in Australia with over 50 instructors and 1,400 members across The Bowen Association Australia (BAA), and The Bowen Therapy Federation of Australasia (BTFA).

BAA and most BTFA members train under the nationally recognised RTO, Bowen Training Australia, and comply with strict continuing education standards. Bowen Therapy offers a fulfilling career and has demonstrated effectiveness in treating various conditions, from back pain to Parkinson's disease. However, since health fund rebates were withdrawn, our membership has dropped from 1,400 in 2017 to 560 today. Without reinstating these rebates, this unique modality risks being lost in Australia.

Bowen Therapy is taught in 32 countries and practised globally. Recently, it was officially recognised as a profession within Bulgaria's vocational educational system, paving the way for similar recognition in other EU countries.
Reinstating the Health Fund Rebate will provide Bowen Therapy with the professional recognition it deserves in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to
• Restore the Private Health Fund Insurance Rebate for Bowen Therapy

when considering the report from the Review of the Australian Government Rebate on Private Health Insurance for Natural Therapies 2019-20 undertaken by The National Health and Medical Research Council on behalf of the Department of Health and Aged Care.
from 1,314 citizens (Petition No. EN6717)
Fringe Benefits Tax

The current Fringe Benefit Tax (FBT) law unfairly penalises small businesses that provide essential support to their employees. While FBT was originally designed to prevent the misuse of benefits in lieu of salary, it has inadvertently created a barrier for businesses wanting to provide crucial support, such as food and water, and health-related assistance. This law must be reformed to enable small businesses to support their employees better without facing prohibitive tax consequences. Many employees earning under $90,000 annually struggle with the rising cost of living, particularly for essential items like food and health services.

We therefore ask the House to consider FBT exemption for a maximum cap of $6,000 per annum on food, non-alcoholic beverages, and health support provided to each eligible SBE's employees. This exemption would be limited to employees earning an annual taxable income of $90,000 or less. The rationale behind this proposal is straightforward: small businesses should not be discouraged from offering basic support to workers who need it the most. The proposed exemption would encourage small businesses to invest in their employees' health and well-being, promoting a more productive and engaged workforce.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6725)
Workplace Relations: Uber
1. Ongoing Violations of the Migration Amendment (Employer Sanctions) Act 2013: Uber has consistently breached this legislation in Australia over the past six years.
2. Misclassification of Drivers: Uber has illegally classified drivers as independent contractors while using various coercive methods to compel them to work.

3. Engagement in Modern Slavery Practices: The company penalizes drivers by stripping away benefits when they decline unprofitable trip requests, contributing to a culture of exploitation although they are classified as independent contractors.
4. Inadequate Safety Protocols: Uber fails to implement sufficient safety measures for drivers, particularly those working during nighttime hours.
5. Exploitation of Vulnerable Workers: Many drivers face exploitation due to inaccurate fare calculations and an unjust fare structure that undermines their earnings.
We therefore ask the House to cancel Uber's business registration in Australia unless it rectifies its business structure and impose fines, sanctions, and penalties for all violations.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN6728)
Vexatious Litigation
The Government has encouraged victims to speak up but has not provided legal protections to protect victims from Strategic Litigation Against Public Participation (SLAPP) cases.

The lack of SLAPP protections means that victims who have reported abuse to their workplace or police have been attacked by the perpetrator using SLAPP litigation to silence the victim and to financially punish them severely for reporting threats, abuse or intimidation.

A typical SLAPP strategy occurs when the perpetrator does not expect to win the legal case, but uses the legal system to silence their victim, who often bears crippling legal costs to defend themselves.

The perpetrators are able to use their financial power to inflict inordinate further harm upon the victim. Disturbingly, SLAPPing may continue for many years. Victims may lose their house and job and future income.

Perpetrators also use legal processes including bankruptcy proceedings to stalk, intimidate and terrify their victims, using information gained through legal processes. Bankruptcy also prevents the victim appealing wrongful decisions of a court, depriving them of any access to justice.

We therefore ask the House to urgently call on the Attorney-General to enact Anti-SLAPPing legislation to protect victims from vexatious (SLAPP) litigation. Further, we request that the Federal, state and territory Attorneys-General intervene to rescue and compensate victims who have been unjustly deprived of their incomes and assets by SLAPP cases.
from 137 citizens (Petition No. EN6729)
Disability Services: Child Care

Families with children who have disabilities face significant financial challenges due to the limitations of the current Childcare Subsidy (CCS). The CCS cap is the same for all families, but for those whose children require specialised care—often involving higher staff-to-child ratios and tailored support—the costs are much higher. This creates a financial burden that many families cannot bear.

Without affordable childcare, parents are forced to reduce work hours, leave their jobs, or use inappropriate care options because they cannot afford the specialised services their children need. For families already managing the daily complexities of raising a child with a disability, this added financial pressure causes significant stress and isolation.

Specialised services like Ruby & Ollie's All Abilities Childcare provide the critical support these children need, but due to the CCS cap, families are left with large out-of-pocket expenses, further straining their finances.
We therefore ask the House to
Review and Increase the Childcare Subsidy (CCS) Cap for families of children with disabilities to reflect the higher costs of specialised care.
Establish a Specialised Childcare Support Fund to help providers cover the additional costs of offering high staff ratios, customised programs, and tailored care.
These changes would ensure families can access affordable childcare and that specialised services can continue meeting the needs of children with disabilities.
from 432 citizens (Petition No. EN6731)
Migration

We, the undersigned, are writing to express our deep concern over the excessive delays in visa processing. Many of us have been waiting for over 16 months without any update or assignment to a case officer. This prolonged waiting period is not only causing significant anxiety and stress but is also severely impacting our ability to move forward with our lives.

While we understand that certain occupations, such as nurses, are receiving expedited visa processing, we feel that this priority system has resulted in unfair treatment of many other applicants. It is disheartening to see some applicants receive their visa grants within just a few days, while others are left in limbo for well over a year.

We believe that everyone deserves equal treatment, regardless of their occupation, and that the current system is leaving too many people in the dark, unsure of their future. Many of us have families and personal plans that are being disrupted due to these delays, and it is time for the Department of Home Affairs to address the backlog.

We urge the government to prioritise clearing the backlog of pending visa applications and to implement a fair and transparent system that ensures timely processing for all applicants. It is essential that visa applicants are treated with the respect and consideration they deserve.
We respectfully request urgent action to address this issue.
We therefore ask the House to clear the backlog of visa applications. Prioritise the ones already in the system for months.
from 78 citizens (Petition No. EN6732)
Telecommunications

Roughly 740,000 4G phones will be unable to make calls to 000 and emergency services if the 3G network is shut down. In 2023, almost 3 Million devices in Australia were reported to be reliant on 3G Network infrastructure, including many phones, cars, EFTPOS machines, tablets, and security cameras. An estimated 200,000 of these devices are medical alarms. A 3G Shutdown would render these unusable, with the user possibly unaware until the device is needed. Not only does a rushed 3G Network shut-down put lives at possible risk, it can likely cause millions of otherwise functioning devices to be discarded, further impacting environmental conservation efforts. Improper electronics disposal may also cause contamination of air, soil, dust, and water with toxic chemicals

We therefore ask the House to thoroughly investigate the nation-wide 3G shut-down, and guarantee that regional people with limited cell reception and otherwise vulnerable individuals will not be left without access to vital emergency services. We urge the House of Representatives to ensure marginalised communities or areas are not left behind, and Australia continues to provide equitable access to the vital infrastructure maintaining principals of equitable access and affordability, something carriers pushing for the 3G Shut-down and mandatory device upgrades that are otherwise unnecessary have yet to prove.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6733)
Broadband

Internet service providers (ISPs) like Telstra, Optus, and Vodafone, charge top dollar for internet that is barely functional. When you complain they'll pass the buck of responsibility to NBN. When the technician says the lines are fine, it goes no further.
I would like to petition for more responsibility over the services ISPs provide and reduced prices where customers are incapable of reaching advertised speeds and stability.

Suburban customers with fiber to the premises (FTP) and fiber to the node (FTN) are having constant drop outs and slow & inconsistent speeds. There is no real investigation into why this is happening.
Rural customers are pushed into alternatives like Starlink, which is not affordable for everyone.
We would like to know:
- Is the issue in the lines, and therefore NBN's responsibility?
- Is this an issue with poor quality modems being provided by ISPs?
- Why are we being charged for premium speeds when so many consumers are experiencing quite the opposite?
- Should there be a price reduction for customers with unstable internet?
- Should there be more responsibility placed on ISPs to fix issues or advocate for their consumers?

We therefore ask the House to please begin an investigation into the quality of the NBN lines, the responsibility of Internet Service Providers and NBN to provide functional internet if they're going to be charging for it.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6734)

subdebateinfo.title: Hospitals: Sexual and Reproductive Health Services

p.span: Hospitals: Sexual and Reproductive Health Services

In 2019, Labor pledged to offer abortion services in public hospitals. Opposition spokesperson for Women, Tanya Plibersek, committed to requiring public hospitals to offer termination services as part of their Commonwealth funding arrangement. The Albanese Government has failed to implement this. This is not just an issue for the states, the federal government has the power to require public hospitals to provide these services. At a time when reproductive healthcare has become a subject of debate in multiple jurisdictions, mimicking the United States, it is more important than ever to increase access. Currently, abortion services are a postcode lottery in Australia. Between high out-of-pocket costs, a scarcity of abortion clinics and the widespread refusal of religious providers to offer this form of healthcare mean that reproductive services are inaccessible and remain stigmatised. Rural and remote Australians feel this burden significantly.
The Albanese Government can and must require public hospitals to offer these services in order to retain their federal funding.
We therefore ask the House to require public hospitals to offer abortion services as part of their Commonwealth funding arrangement.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN6735)
International Students

Many international students who graduate from Australian institutions and live and work in the country for over 3 to 5 years have already demonstrated their English proficiency through academic and professional achievements. Requiring additional English tests for these individuals creates unnecessary barriers and adds financial and emotional strain. While a competent level of English should be maintained as a requirement, prioritizing superior or proficient scores over lived experience and contribution to society disadvantages long-term temporary residents who are already integrated into Australian society and contribute meaningfully to the economy and workforce of Australia.

We therefore ask the House to waive the mandatory English language test requirement for permanent residency (PR) applicants who have studied at Australian universities/institutions and have lived and worked in Australia for at least three to five years. While a competent English level can remain a baseline requirement, applicants should not be unfairly penalized or deprioritized based on language test scores when they have clearly demonstrated their contribution and integration into Australian society.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6738)
Congo: Cobalt Mining Industry
Kids and adults in Congo are being forced into mining cobalt every day. They risk their lives going into the mines without any safety, and they have twenty minutes of oxygen.
We therefore ask the House to give funding to Congo to buy more machinery and safety gear for the community in Congo's local cobalt mine
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN6739)
Sport: Discrimination
The year nine student from Sydney's North Shore has the most common type of short-limbed dwarfism—achondroplasia. Paralympic swimming medallist Sarah Rose threw her support behind Hugo.
"In a world where we can be anything, let's be kind. I really hope this decision is reversed," she said.

"Thinking of you Hugo." "It's the thing I love the most and it's been taken away from me," Hugo Russell told 7News. "Halfway through the run, I get a feeling that I can't stop, otherwise I'll be so disappointed in myself and I just like that feeling of running and it just makes me happy." Please let us get Hugo over the finish line.
We therefore ask the House to investigate discrimination in Australia's athletics governing body that has ruled people with dwarfism are not allowed to run long distances in organised events.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6741)
Judiciary
The Introduction of a Federal Judicial Commission is needed to investigate complaints made about Federal Judicial Officers.
The Australian Government has
announced and welcomes the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) Report 138, Without Fear or Favour: Judicial Impartiality and the Law on Bias.

The ALRC made 14 recommendations to promote and protect judicial impartiality and public confidence in the Commonwealth judiciary that was directed to the Federal Court for consideration and action, namely the High Court of Australia, Federal Court of Australia and Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia.

The Attorney-General, the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC MP, announced on 17 January 2023 the "Scoping the Establishment of a Federal Judicial Commission" with approx 57 submissions received during that consultation process which ended on 21 February 2023.
The Australian Government has made declarations to support the proposal of an Independent Federal Judicial Commission, however has yet to take any action to implement those changes to date.

The current process is vastly inadequate, to say the least with the Chief Justice/Chief Judge being responsible for managing these complaints. However, there is a history of these complaints being referred back to the Judge for review and self-recusal.

This proposal will restore the administration of justice for all Australians, not only ensuring that justice is both done and seen to be done and the fundamental principles of procedural fairness, including that decision-makers must be independent and impartial.
We therefore ask the House to The Introduction of a Federal Judicial Commission to investigate complaints made about Federal Judicial Officers.
from 62 citizens (Petition No. EN6746)
Obesity

Wegovy should be included on the Australian PBS because it offers an effective, medically-approved solution for managing obesity, a condition that affects millions of Australians and increases the risk of serious health issues like heart disease, diabetes, and stroke. By making Wegovy more affordable and accessible through the PBS, individuals struggling with obesity can receive the treatment they need to improve their health outcomes, reduce healthcare costs associated with obesity-related illnesses, and enhance their quality of life. As a long-term, sustainable weight management tool, Wegovy could play a crucial role in addressing Australia's obesity epidemic.

We therefore ask the House to respectfully ask the House to take immediate action in including the obesity medication Wegovy on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). With obesity affecting millions of Australians and contributing to significant public health challenges, it is vital that effective treatments be made accessible to those in need. By subsidizing Wegovy through the PBS, the government would ensure that individuals from all walks of life can afford this essential medication, helping to reduce the prevalence of obesity-related health issues and easing the strain on Australia's healthcare system. We urge the House to prioritize the health of Australians by making this life-changing treatment more widely available.re ask the House to
from 92 citizens (Petition No. EN6747)
Parliamentary Standards
Recently the media announced our Prime Minister spent $4,300,000 on a new home.
This sort of thing might be fine and dandy in real life but Tony Albanese is our Prime Minister and is supposed to be looking after our country not his wallet.

We therefore ask the House to implement rules or legislation so that Members of Parliament sell all their assets except the family home and that money put in trust until they stop being parliamentarians. Family trusts should also be included in those assets sold upon election.

If parliamentarians do well in looking after the country they will guarantee their wealth remains the same or even increases during their time as politicians. When an MP retires or resigns or loses their seat they will be given their money to reinvest in whatever they want.

This will have the added benefit of having MPs looking after our country instead of thinking and acting in a way to benefit their investments. As a voter I think I am seeing politicians doing things to make themselves, their family companies and trusts wealthier. This is not good.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6749)
Family Law

Child support should be based on your base salary/income. It's hard enough to start again. Trying to better one's self and get in front by working overtime should not come in to child support assessments. This is not about not paying for your children, it's about paying a fair amount.
When I had to leave my children due to a toxic and violent relationship I left them with only a tv, single bed and a payment of 50k for a house worth 700k.

I was earning about 60k a year in a government job. We had a private agreement which was more than enough to feed and clothe my children. Now that I have bettered myself and have a job with the opportunity for overtime.
Im finally in a position after 10 year of hard work I can now start to live, but due to the current system it just goes to the ex who sits at home working part time.

If I was to become ill of miss work I would still be expected to pay the payment based of my income including my overtime even if I hadn't work overtime. The system is wrong and I believe it is a major contributor to suicide in young men that can't afford to live.
We therefore ask the House to Review the system, remove the overtime from the assessment. Base salary only
from 231 citizens (Petition No. EN6752)
Banking and Financial Services

It has now come to the point where the biggest cost of Government is interest paid on debt. This means Australia's debt of over 2 trillion dollars now exceeds the ability of Australians to ever pay back. I therefore propose the Government abolish compound interest charged by money lenders for all money borrowed by and for Australians.
We therefore ask the House to carry a motion to investigate abolishing compound interest charged by money lenders, for current and future loans given to Australian government, business and citizens.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN6753)
Endometriosis

The number of individuals affected by endometriosis and pelvic pain conditions in our region is growing. These debilitating conditions continue to rise, highlighting an urgent need for comprehensive care. We advocate for establishing a state-of-the-art clinic, staffed by world-class, local medical specialists, to provide the necessary support and treatment these women and girls deserve.
We therefore ask the House to consider Newcastle as the site for the next Endometriosis and Pelvic Pain Clinic under the Federal Governments delivery program.
from 57 citizens (Petition No. EN6754)
Taxation

It's 2024, there should be no need for PAYG individuals to even be concerned with how their income tax works, let alone need to do a return every year. The system for such individuals should be entirely automated and work in the background with no intervention from the tax payer unless issues arise. This has been the case in the UK for many decades now and I do not believe anybody alive today there has ever done their own end of year tax unless they run a business. It's high time Australia caught up in this regard. This would also cut annual costs down to the average resident by eliminating completely all bills paid to tax accountants except for business purposes, so all tax paying residents will benefit from this change.

We therefore ask the House to automate the annual ATO tax return for individuals, so there is zero need for any non business entity to process their own tax returns and get Australia up to the 21st century and save them money in the process.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN6755)
Judiciary

The devastating impact and lasting effect of a wrongful conviction regardless of exoneration is a tremendous miscarriage of justice and such situations should be properly rectified. The current gap in legislation does not allow for wrongfully imprisoned individuals to receive legal compensation for their time served. The financial, physical, social and psychological struggles exonerees face after prison is in every way attributable to errors in judicial processes. International law details the right to compensation as necessary if a person is subject to arbitrary detention. The lack of consistency, transparency and accountability displayed through current compensatory pathways is not reflective of a fair and equitable system.

We therefore ask the House to retract the reservation to Article 14 of the ICCPR allowing for compensation through "administrative procedures" and ratify standardized legislation granting the wrongfully convicted their rightful compensation.
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN6757)
Australian Currency
It is not fair and discrimination that government encourage no cash in future.
We therefore ask the House to stop no cash policy and not allow not to use cash in community as cash is legal currency.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6759)
Air Safety

This petition urges the Australian Parliament to adopt a UAP disclosure policy similar to the United States' UAP Disclosure Act of 2024. With the growing global momentum toward transparency in Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena (UAP) research, Australia, a nation with a rich history of UAP sightings, has a unique responsibility to ensure transparency and accountability in its handling of UAP-related information.

We therefore ask the House to introduce legislation to declassify UAP-related government records, modeled after the U.S. Disclosure Act. By declassifying UAP documents, Australia can foster public trust, contribute to scientific and technological progress, and enhance national security through open discourse on UAP risks and opportunities.

The global movement toward UAP disclosure gained momentum with the U.S. Congress passing legislation requiring systematic declassification of UAP records, with limited exceptions for national security. Australian citizens deserve similar transparency, especially given the public's rising interest in UAP phenomena.
We call for Parliament to:
Declassify all UAP-related documents held by Australian defense and government agencies.
Establish a UAP oversight body to manage declassification while balancing security concerns.
Create a publicly accessible UAP archive within the National Archives of Australia.

This petition represents a commitment to transparency and public understanding of an important issue. We trust Parliament will follow the United States' example, align Australia with global standards, and demonstrate a commitment to governmental openness and accountability on UAPs.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6761)
Parenting Payment

Increase the widow/widower single parent pension to help decrease the disadvantage of those children who are already grieving a parent. Widow/widower parents receive the same benefits as separated/divorced parents who still have rights to claim child support. These children are already financially disadvantaged after losing a parent, understandably they often have trauma problems. The single parent left behind needs more support from the community, including financially.

We therefore ask the House to increase the widow/widower single parent pension, adding at very least the same amount as an average child support payment. Closing the financial gap for already disadvantaged children & families.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN6763)
Parenting Payment
We, the undersigned, call upon the Australian Parliament to amend existing legislation to allow New Zealand citizens who are single parents to access Single Parenting Payments from Centrelink.

Many New Zealand citizens residing in Australia face significant barriers when seeking government assistance, particularly as single parents. Due to a variety of foreseen and unforeseen circumstances, many struggle to make ends meet, and the inability to access adequate support exacerbates financial hardship across our communities.

Many single parents find it challenging to gain employment due to caregiving responsibilities, leaving them in vulnerable financial situations. This petition seeks to address this inequity and support NZ citizens who contribute to Australian society and economy.
We therefore ask the House to take swift action to ensure that all single parents, regardless of their nationality, receive the support they need to thrive.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6773)
Trade with China

Australia and China have recently agreed to remove trade obstacles so that we can further enhance our two-way trade partnership. Indeed, this will provide significant benefits to lobster business and support the broader economy. I believe that we should now shift away from stabilising our relations with China and instead focus on development.

The belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has supported various countries in realising their developmental aspirations. In fact it is our closest neighbour, Indonesia, which has been given access to high speed rail. This initiative would reap significant benefits for our country as we could seek to bring communities together. In particular there could be implications for our First Nations people living in remote regions as we can speed up the process of food deliveries and essential aid.

We therefore ask the House to recommend that our foreign relations minister penny wong raise that the prospect of joining the Belt and Road Initiative in our next high level dialogue between Australia and China and to the Chinese premier Li Qiang.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN6774)
Census

The Yazidi community in Australia plays a vital role in enriching the nation's cultural diversity. Despite this, Yazidi language, religion, and ethnicity remain unrecognized in national data, making it difficult to accurately assess the needs of this community and provide tailored support. Recognizing Yazidi identity in the 2026 Australian Census will ensure fair representation and enable policymakers to better address the social, educational, and economic challenges faced by Yazidis. This recognition is a crucial step toward preserving Yazidi heritage, ensuring equitable access to resources, and promoting the community's integration and well-being within Australian society.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Australian Bureau of Statistics to include Yazidi language, religion, and ethnicity as distinct categories in the 2026 Australian Census. This recognition will enable accurate representation of the Yazidi community, support the development of targeted policies, and ensure equitable access to resources and services for Yazidi Australians. By doing so, the government will take an essential step toward promoting cultural preservation, inclusion, and the well-being of this historically marginalized group.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN6775)
Centrelink
Centrelink is democratic support. Reasons for suspending Centrelink include Homelessness, Bad-health and Flux Stability. There should be no persons without income.
We therefore ask the House to legally ban Centrelink and Employment Agencies from suspending Centrelink payments. Non-compliance should banned and use Employment Agencies as social support.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN6776)
International Students
Financial and Time Investment:

International students at G8 universities invest significant financial resources and time in their education, expecting to qualify for the 485 Visa upon graduation. The new age limit disproportionately affects those who planned their studies based on previous visa regulations.
Career Development:
The ability to work in Australia after graduation is crucial for gaining relevant experience, enhancing employability, and contributing to the Australian economy.
Those who arrived in Australia before the law change made educational and career plans based on prior criteria.
Recognition of Academic Excellence:
Graduates from G8 universities, known for high academic standards, should be recognized for their qualifications and provided fair access to opportunities to utilize their skills in Australia.
Support for Mental Health and Wellbeing:
The uncertainty surrounding visa status can lead to stress and anxiety. Exemptions would alleviate this pressure, allowing graduates to focus on their career paths and well-being.
Contribution to Society:
International students significantly contribute to Australia's cultural diversity, innovation, and economic growth. Allowing them to remain and work enhances the Australian community and workforce.
Exemptions for those who arrived before the law change uphold principles of equity.
We therefore ask the House to urge the Australian government to consider the following actions regarding the Temporary Graduate Visa (Subclass 485):
Review Visa Policies
Introduce Exemptions: Create exemptions to the 35-year age limit specifically for international students who enrolled in G8 universities and arrived in Australia before the recent law change.
from 287 citizens (Petition No. EN6778)
Barrington Tops: Cessna VH-MDX Crash

Light aircraft, tail number VH-MDX a Cessna 210, went missing on the 9th August 1981 over the Barrington Tops NSW with five men on board. Despite the initial & continuing ongoing foot searches over the last 43 years, no trace of the aircraft or occupants have been located. Given the difficult topography of the terrain & dense vegetation, foot searching is difficult, abhorrently slow & also very dangerous. People are putting their lives at risk in trying to locate the aircraft. But above all, its the five family's still waiting for news of their lost ones still 43 years later. Its time these missing men are finally found & returned to their respective family's finally giving them closure.

We therefore ask the House to to seek & utilze alternate methods to assist in locating the missing aircraft/men. This could include modern state of the art remote sensing equipment not available in 1981. LIDAR flown at low level by UAV or helicopter could possibly locate the aircraft below the vegetation. The use of SAR (synthetic aperture radar) is another option, possibly available through RAAF, ADF or Army. Lastly, Further on foot search efforts coordinated by the Army.
from 276 citizens (Petition No. EN6781)
Taxation
We ask the House of Representatives to restore the original Reduced Input Tax Credit (RITC) interpretation that has been in place since the introduction of GST legislation in 2000.

The RITC is a Goods and Services Tax (GST) rebate on certain fees charged through a platform. Historically, it allowed Funds and IDPS Operators to claim a rebate from the ATO on the GST applied to financial advice fees, effectively providing investors with a 75% discount on the GST charged on these fees.

In July 2024, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) altered its interpretation of the RITC, resulting in super funds and IDPS operators losing the ability to claim this rebate on behalf of their members. This change has effectively increased the GST on clients' advice fees from 2.5% to 10%, representing a 7.3% overall increase in the fees charged to clients.

Previously, a client receiving a $1,100 (including GST) advice fee would have received a $75 credit, resulting in a net payment of $1,025. As of July 1st, 2024, clients are now charged the full $1,100.

It's important to note that no legislative change has prompted this; rather, the ATO has reinterpreted long-standing legislation, despite numerous private rulings supporting the original interpretation. This reinterpretation amounts to a hidden tax increase, further exacerbating the rising cost of financial advice for Australians, especially at a time when accessible financial advice is crucial.
We therefore ask the House to take action and reinstate the original RITC interpretation.
from 1,449 citizens (Petition No. EN6786)
Drug Abuse and Addiction: Paracetamol
February the number of pills in Paracetamol packages will be reduced and restricted.
According to the TGA is for the purpose of stopping Suicide of young people.
This not the first time the government has restricted access to what is normally seen as Off the Shelf drugs in most countries.
Antihistamines ias another example.
Restricting access does not have the desired effect instead it increases prices and inconveniences the vast majority of responsible people.

We therefore ask the House to review ALL the restrictions of non prescription pharmaceuticals and reverse any restrictions that are for limiting access to them for reasons of self harm or drug trafficking.
Drug Traffics ALLWAYS bypass the law, it's exactly what they do.
The Nanny approach to Self Harm doesn't work either, they either work around the restrictions or find an alternative.
We request that you act in the interest of the MAJORITY of RESPONSIBLE citizens and STOP punishing and inconveniencing them for the questionable benefit of a miniscule minority.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN6787)
Digital Media Content

Digital media such as games, movies and music are extremely popular in Australia but when we purchase this content we are only buying a license that lasts only as long as the digital service provider hosts that content. if the digital service provider decides they no longer want to host that content then the consumer loses access to the content they have purchased.

for example: statistics show in 2023 over 21 million Australians played video games, if 6 million of those players had purchased a game at $100 each that would equal $600 million dollars. If a digital service provider decided to no longer host that game and remove it from their store it would cost those consumers $600 million dollars and countless hours of time invested.
this clearly shows an imbalance in the rights of consumers when purchasing digital content.

We therefore ask the House to enact legislation to require businesses to provide consumers with direct ownership of digital products so they may remain in a functional state past the end of the the digital products support period.
we ask that the right to direct ownership supersede terms and conditions set by the business or digital service provider.
we ask that businesses and digital service providers must include a consumers right to direct ownership over purchased digital content in their terms and conditions
we ask that when purchasing a digital license for a product the terminology "Rent" replace "purchase" and "buy" as those terms indicate a consumers right to direct ownership.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6788)
Freedom of Speech

On Monday the 28th of October, 2024, Australia's immigration minister Tony Burke announced that he has denied Candace Owens entry into this country on the grounds that her views may incite discord in all directions.
Section 16 of the Human Rights Act 2004 (ACT) states that: Everyone has the right to hold opinions without interference. Everyone has the right to freedom of expression.

We the undersigned believe that Tony Burkes decision is not only a misrepresentation of the Australian people's views, but also a huge step backwards for freedom of speech in this country, and a clear example of political censorship.
It is not within the rights of any politician to decide who the Australian people listen to, and we reserve the right to decide for ourselves whether we agree or disagree with any public figure.
We therefore ask the House to allow Candace Owens entry into Australia, and we demand that the political censorship of information available to Australians immediately cease.
from 38 citizens (Petition No. EN6789)

subdebateinfo.title: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse

p.span: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse

We, the undersigned, call for an urgent investigation into the unacceptable delays and lack of transparency within the National Redress Scheme. Survivors of institutional abuse deserve timely and compassionate responses, yet many applicants are waiting more than 12 months for outcomes without meaningful updates or clear timelines.

The current process is shrouded in secrecy, leaving survivors in the dark with little recourse for inquiry or support. Generic and impersonal responses are routinely provided, offering no insight into the status of claims or reasons for delays. This lack of communication exacerbates trauma for those already navigating the complex and painful journey toward redress.

This petition seeks accountability and reform to ensure the Scheme operates with the dignity, empathy, and efficiency survivors deserve. Survivors should not be further burdened by uncertainty and neglect while seeking justice. We urge immediate action to restore confidence in this essential process.
We therefore ask the House to investigate:
The reasons behind delays exceeding 12 months;
The lack of personalised communication provided to applicants; and
The structural and procedural barriers that prevent transparent and timely resolution of claims.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6790)
Product Labelling: Palm Oil

Palm oil is a necessary ingredient in many products, however its production is often devastating to the environment. It's in around 50% of packaged foods, usually under a different name like "vegetable oil." Palm oil can be produced sustainably but it often isn't, leading to habitat loss for elephants, orangutans and other animals. Mandatory palm oil labelling allows consumers to make a more informed choice, and will encourage companies to source sustainable palm oil.

We therefore ask the House to make it mandatory for all products (both food and non-food items) that use palm oil to list palm oil by name in the item's ingredient list. They should no longer be permitted to use names such as, but not limited to:

Vegetable Oil, Vegetable Fat, Palm Kernel, Palm Kernel Oil, Palm Fruit Oil, Palmate, Palmitate, Palmolein, Glyceryl, Stearate, Stearic Acid, Elaeis Guineensis, Palmitic Acid, Palm Stearine, Palmitoyl Oxostearamide, Palmitoyl Tetrapeptide-3, Sodium Laureth Sulfate, Sodium Lauryl Sulfate, Sodium Kernelate, Sodium Palm Kernelate, Sodium Lauryl Lactylate/Sulphate, Hyrated Palm Glycerides, Etyl Palmitate, Octyl Palmitate, Palmityl Alcohol (list taken from Melbourne Zoo's "Don't Palm Us Off campaign" but is in no way affiliated with Melbourne Zoo).
from 106 citizens (Petition No. EN6792)
Freedom of Speech

Candace Owens has been banned from Australia. This is unjust and un-Australian, we are a country of freedom. We allow all races and religions to protest in the street, but we won't allow an intelligent journalist to speak on issues that are important to many Australians. Let's stand up for everyone to have a voice, regardless of their point of view. She hasn't broken any laws, this is based off the personal feelings of Tony Burke which is no reason to ban someone.
We therefore ask the House to overturn Candaces visa ban
from 64 citizens (Petition No. EN6799)

subdebateinfo.title: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Autism

p.span: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and Autism

The petition is aimed at urging the Australian Government to reduce the high costs of ADHD and Autism assessments. These assessments are crucial for individuals to access support services, educational accommodations, and workplace adjustments. However, with assessments costing between $700 and $3,000, many people are financially unable to obtain a diagnosis. Without a diagnosis, they are left without access to essential resources that help them manage daily life and reach their full potential. The petition seeks to make these assessments more accessible and affordable, alleviating financial burdens and empowering individuals affected by ADHD and Autism.
We therefore ask the House to improve accessibility and affordability of ADHD and Autism assessments.
We request:
- Increased Medicare Rebates for these assessments to reduce out-of-pocket costs.
- Subsidized Support Programs to assist lower-income individuals and families in obtaining diagnoses.
- Greater Funding for Public Mental Health Services to reduce wait times and increase specialist availability.
- Creation of a National Task Force focused on identifying and addressing barriers to affordable neurodevelopmental assessments.

These steps will help ensure Australians affected by ADHD and Autism can access essential diagnostic services, paving the way for support in education, employment, and daily life. The House's action on this matter will foster inclusivity, allowing individuals to unlock their potential with the support they need.
from 2,169 citizens (Petition No. EN6801)
National Anti-Corruption Commission

I am seeking the termination of employment contract of Paul Brereton due to the findings of NACC inspector. I don't believe that such an experienced person as Mr Brereton could make such a "simple mistake" and given this commission goes to the very core of ethical behaviour I fail to see how he could continue in the role. This sort of oversight of duties would not be acceptable in any public organisations and can not be tolerated in the NACC if Australians are to have faith in this body. If the former head of Australia Post can be effectively "sacked" by parliament for very minor (and disclosed) gift giving, then the NACC Commissioner should have the same applied.
We therefore ask the House to terminate the appointment of Paul Brereton as the NACC and consider also the conduct of the other commissioners who did nothing to act.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN6802)
Myanmar
Humanitarian Crisis: The ongoing civil conflict in Myanmar has led to widespread suffering, with millions displaced and facing severe food and medical shortages.
Human Rights Violations: Reports of atrocities, including extrajudicial killings and arbitrary detentions, are rampant, necessitating immediate international intervention.
Democratic Values: As a nation committed to democracy and human rights, Australia has a responsibility to support the restoration of democratic governance in Myanmar.
Regional Stability: The conflict poses a risk to regional stability in Southeast Asia, affecting neighbouring countries and global security.
We therefore ask the House to
Increase Humanitarian Aid: Provide immediate support to organisations delivering aid to affected communities in Myanmar.
Implement Targeted Sanctions: Enforce sanctions against military leaders responsible for violence, ensuring these measures protect civilians.
Promote Dialogue: Engage in diplomatic efforts with regional partners to foster negotiations between conflicting parties and push for a ceasefire.
Support Civil Society: Fund initiatives that empower local organizations working towards peace and the protection of human rights.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6806)
Israel

In light of Israel's recent ban on UNRWA and its continued non-compliance with ICJ rulings, I urge you to consider the advice of Francesca Albanese, the UN Special Rapporteur on the occupied Palestinian territories, and call for the suspension of Israel from the United Nations General Assembly.

As outlined in Ms. Albanese's latest report, Israel has shown flagrant disregard for numerous UN resolutions, taken the lives of United Nations staff members, and destroyed UN facilities. Israel continues to act with impunity, disregarding the ICJ's ruling to immediately expedite humanitarian aid to the people of Gaza, protect Palestinians in the occupied territories, and withdraw its illegal settlements.
Unseating Israel from the General Assembly would send a clear message that no state can act with impunity when it violates human rights and disregards international law.
We therefore ask the House to seek the suspension of Israel from the United Nations General Assembly.
from 69 citizens (Petition No. EN6808)
Telecommunications

The government should adopt the Rich Communication Services (RCS) messaging standard as a national priority to enhance digital communication. RCS offers a secure, interoperable platform that modernises traditional SMS by enabling features like end-to-end encryption, high-quality multimedia sharing, group chats, and real-time updates all without the need for third-party apps. Implementing RCS would promote competition for the consumer market, reduce dependency on foreign messaging platforms, and ensure that critical communication infrastructure meets the needs of modern society in a secure and accessible manner. We believe this is a necessary step to foster innovation and strengthen the nation's digital ecosystem.

We therefore ask the House to take immediate action to adopt the Rich Communication Services (RCS) messaging standard across all mobile networks and devices such as iPhones's with iOS 18 and Android Phones within the country. This includes mandating its implementation as the default messaging protocol to promote the technology, staying away from SMS, ensuring interoperability among service providers, and providing the necessary regulatory framework to protect consumer privacy and data security. By doing so, the government would foster a more secure, reliable, and feature-rich communication infrastructure that meets the demands of modern digital communication while promoting fair competition and innovation in the telecom sector.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6811)
Family Law
It's totally unfair for men in marriages to lose half their assets & kids under current anti-men laws, given men entered marriages before these new anti-men laws were put into place.
Men would never have married 20+ years ago had men known current laws would be so anti-men.
We therefore ask the House to pass a new law to allow men to leave their marriage without any penalty to men.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6814)
United States of America

Certain citizens of Australia who support international democracy, the rule of law, and civic peace, are implacably opposed to the US Congress having any powers to arrest, detain, and deport US Citizens based on their race. This racial persecution would violate international law and we invite Australia's elected officials to publicly condemn former US President Trump and his divisive and racist agenda.

We therefore ask the House to collectively sign a public international statement condemning former US President Donald Trump and his plan to divide the United States with his legislative mandate to arrest, detain, and deport US Citizens based on their race.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6816)
National Security

We respectfully urge the Government of Australia to take decisive action to prevent foreign nationals from using places of worship as platforms for their agendas and propaganda. Such misuse poses significant risks as these sacred spaces are intended for peace, reflection, and community unity, not political or ideological manipulation. Evidence shows that foreign agencies often exploit religious venues to infiltrate Australian society, sowing seeds of division and hate. Numerous instances, both abroad and on Australian soil, have demonstrated how this practice undermines social cohesion and national security. It is imperative for Australia to safeguard its religious institutions from becoming tools for external influences that threaten the harmony and values that form the foundation of our diverse society.

We therefore ask the House to bring in law or ruling that prohibits foreign consulates from using religious places for any official work, or participate in any event with the religious places as representatives of foreign state.
from 297 citizens (Petition No. EN6817)
Media
A petition to reduce partisanship in the media landscape, bias and "fact-checking", and restore media to a place where news is told straight. Instead the

media will provide information to people and allow individuals to think for themselves rather than the media thinking for people, controlling the narrative and questioning when that is the responsibility of political parties/individuals and the public.
A fairness doctrine would ensure the news is presented with balance, and that differing viewpoints are reflected fairly.
the fairness doctrine would only apply to dedicated news segments (not entertainment)

We therefore ask the House to legislate a policy that would force media to abide by a code of fairness, making it a requirement for networks to dedicate a specific time to controversial issues, and for those issues to be presented in a fair manner. A requirement for a network to hold it's licence (for broadcasting) is adherence to the fairness doctrine (in regards to news presentation).
We also request the fairness doctrine apply to Digital Media, Newspapers, Radio, Internet/video news components.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6819)
Tertiary Education

There are 1000s of citizens return to higher education or a large number wanting to study in their late age to reskill them through acquiring new skills in new areas. For eg. A long-time plumber wanting to pursue higher education in Nursing, or a long-time psychologist wanting to pursue higher education in Law, a long-time electrician wanting to pursue higher education in construction, etc. This is a great advantage for the country and economy. However financial situation does not allow or severely burden these reskilling efforts given higher age group and the unaffordable HECS debt. Not many in this category receive commonwealth supported places and vast majority drop the plan to reskill and re learn. Therefore, a change in funding and subsidising required to ensure increased funding for this specific category of people above certain age and wanting to learn a totally new area of studies.

We therefore ask the House to formulate new subsidy and financial help for those reskilling in a new area of study in higher education by at least 60% of the fee, for those who are not supported by current commonwealth support.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6820)
Iran
We are calling on the Australian Government to impose sanctions on Iran due to alarming reports of violence and human rights abuses against Afghan migrants at the Iran.

Recently, Iranian border guards reportedly opened fire on a group of Afghan migrants attempting to enter the country, resulting in the death of over 200 people, with only a few survivors. These individuals were seeking safety and a better life but instead faced brutal treatment and loss of life.

This incident is part of a broader pattern of mistreatment towards Afghan refugees in Iran, including detentions, deportations, and a sharp increase in executions. According to human right organisation Afghan citizens in Iran face harsh discrimination, violence, and restricted access to basic rights.

As Australians, we cannot stand by in silence while such violations of human right take place. Australia has a history of supporting humanitarian efforts and promoting human rights on the global stage. By implementing sanctions, our government can send a strong message condemning Iran's actions and urging accountability.
We ask the Australian Government to stand with the Afghan community, protect human rights, and take meaningful action to prevent further violence and discrimination against Afghan refugees in Iran.
We therefore ask the House to impose targeted sanctions on Iran, specifically against officials responsible for human rights abuses against Afghan Migrants.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6821)
Miscarriage, Stillbirth and Neonatal Death
In Australia, 1 in 4 women experience pregnancy or infant loss, with six stillborn babies and two neonatal deaths each day.

The deaths of our children have shattered our hearts. Yet, we are left without answers, support, lack of research into causes, and the reassurance that something is being done to prevent other families from enduring this same pain.
We therefore ask the House to take action in these areas:

1. Funding for Life-Saving Research: Fund dedicated research into the causes and prevention of pregnancy loss, premature birth, and stillbirth. For too long, this research has been underfunded, leaving parents like us with unanswerable questions and heartbreak.
2. Establishing a National Registry: Create a national registry to collect critical data on pregnancy and infant loss, to help uncover patterns, risk factors, and potential prevention strategies.

3. Public Awareness and Education: Help end the silence and stigma around pregnancy and infant loss. Our stories should be heard, and others should be aware of the prevalence of this pain that so many of us suffer quietly.

4. Reducing Healthcare Inequality: Disparities in healthcare access and outcomes persist, with some groups experiencing higher rates of stillbirth and pregnancy complications. Targeted research can highlight these disparities and inform policies to ensure equitable access to prenatal and neonatal care.

5. Reducing Economic Burden: Pregnancy complications and infant loss can have significant economic impacts on healthcare systems, families, and society. Investing in research could reduce costs associated with complications, medical treatments, and long-term emotional support services.
from 276 citizens (Petition No. EN6822)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

Remedial massage, a proven support under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), remains unfunded when provided by qualified remedial massage therapists. Currently, only AHPRA-registered practitioners are permitted to deliver remedial massage through the scheme, despite the fact that remedial massage therapists hold nationally-recognised diploma qualifications in their field.

Remedial massage therapists already have an established health care identity. They are recognised as health care practitioners by the Department of Health and Aged Care, and by private health insurance companies. They are also already recognised as allied health care practitioners for the purposes of providing services through the Home Care Package program.

Qualified remedial massage therapists are specifically trained to assess, plan and treat, providing safe and effective outcomes for individuals with disabilities. Given that remedial massage is recognised as an evidence-based support within the NDIS, it stands to reason that the professionals with the most relevant training and expertise should be allowed to deliver it.
Expanding NDIS coverage to include qualified remedial massage therapists would enhance participant choice, access, and the quality of care.
We therefore ask the House to recognise qualified remedial massage therapists as NDIS providers, allowing participants to access the care they deserve from practitioners best equipped to deliver it.
from 1,857 citizens (Petition No. EN6823)
Taxation
"Cost is the major barrier for many Australians seeking dental care" (Final Report- Senate Select Committee into the
Provision of and Access to Dental Services in Australia, Nov 2023).

With cost barriers in the context of the cost of living crisis affecting everyday Australians, the decline of oral health has led to to increased frequency and cost of managing untreated dental disease.

This cost is largely borne on the personal finances of the everyday Australian, or the State and Federal Governments who must budget for the increased demand for dental treatments as well as the increasing number of "potentially preventable hospitalizations due to dental disease" (AIHW Report 4/10/2024). This is a social, health and financial burden which extends into general health and wellbeing, also putting additional strain and costs on Medicare as patients seek generally ineffective or palliative management through Medicare subsidized GP's for dental diseases.
The inclusion of dental treatment into Medicare is not supported by the Australian Dental Association- the peak representative body for dentists.

There is an exponentially increasing problem of compassionate early release of superannuation for dental treatment due to cost which will significantly impact retirement funds of an individual and presents a future welfare cost risk.
A tax offset for dental expenses will put money back into the hands of taxpayers who have incurred significant costs.
We therefore ask the House to cost and implement a "dental expenses tax offset" commencing FY 2025/2026 modelled off the medical expenses tax offset which was abolished in 2019 to help Australians.
from 440 citizens (Petition No. EN6825)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Embassy: United States of America

p.span: Australian Embassy: United States of America
Kevin Rudd the ambassador to USA. Publicly hates the USA president . This could hurt relations between USA and Australia as good faith with USA he should be sacked for his position
We therefore ask the House to recall ambassador Kevin Rudd from USA and sack him
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN6826)
Film and Video Game Classification

The current way that videogame's are classified are way to harsh and strict. Games like Gta 5 if were a movie would be A MA15+. The main problem is that videogame developers have to be more careful when devloping videogame content. which lot of games that have a R18 or a MA15+ rating would be lower of were a movie. This creates less fun stories and game-play. This create's losses and potential DOA (Dead On Arrival) Games. So im asking to have the guidelines changed
We therefore ask the House to changes the videogame rating system and consider the way the content is presented
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6828)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

The new US President has shown himself to be an anti-democrat with an unpredictable approach to foreign policy. Australia puts itself at risk if we slavishly follow the policies of this man which could lead us into a war that is not in Australia's interests, just as was the war in Vietnam, and in Iraq. We should also stop speaking about 'shared democratic values' with the United States as the basis of this alliance because that has shown not to be the case. The Parliament needs to take a clear-eyed view of Australia's best interests and chart our foreign policy according to those interests, on the assumption that we cannot depend on President Trump's US to help us.

We therefore ask the House to convene a committee or working group f to review the precise terms of the US-Australia alliance, to test those terms against Australia's best interests and in light of the political realities of the next four years, and to scope a policy that would see Australia taking a more neutral, balanced approach in our region in the future that would secure our economic and security needs.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6830)
Israel

Australia, as a signatory to the Geneva Conventions, the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, and the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, has a legal obligation to uphold human rights and prevent atrocity crimes. Recent reports document significant harm to civilians in the Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT), including high death tolls, destruction of healthcare infrastructure, and blockades on essential resources. These actions suggest violations of international humanitarian law, including potential war crimes and crimes against humanity. Many Australians are concerned that Australia's continued support for Israel and lack of meaningful action contradict its obligations under international law.
We therefore ask the House to Representatives to:

1. Impose targeted sanctions on Israeli officials and military leaders involved in actions within the OPT, in accordance with Australia's obligations under the Geneva Conventions and the Rome Statute.
2. Increase transparency and provide regular updates on Australia's actions and policies concerning the conflicts in Israel, Palestine, Syria, Lebanon, Yemen, and Iran.
3. Release any legal advice provided to the government regarding Australia's obligations under international treaties, specifically in relation to the ongoing situation in the OPT.
4. Actively pursue accountability for potential breaches of international law in the OPT, including supporting international investigations into alleged violations of international law.
5. Review Australia's military and trade relations with Israel to ensure these align with Australia's international obligations, and disclose the findings to the Australian public.
Through these actions, we seek to ensure that Australia's foreign policy adheres to its international commitments.
from 117 citizens (Petition No. EN6831)
Cybersafety

The government shouldn't set a national age on social media because parents should be able to make decisions for their children and their should be more education in schools on the dangers of social media not go and make a age limit.
We therefore ask the House to consider not to make a national age limit on social media and instead ask the states and territories to provide more education on the dangers of social media in schools.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN6832)
Australian National Anthem

The current national anthem is of its time and no longer speaks to the modern Australia. Thus we petition the anthem be changed to "We Don't Need Another Hero" by Tina Turner, the title track to the Australian/US coproduction Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome.
It speaks about not being bullied by others, not looking for any single person to change things, and that we, as a community, need to be the hero that changes things. Plus it's a banger.
We therefore ask the House to consider the possibilities of changing the national anthem to "We Don't Need Another Hero" by Tina Turner, with approval from the Turner estate, of course.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6833)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America
Mr. Trump's public record is clear that his actions and statements, well-documented in both the United States and internationally, present grounds for refusal on the basis of character.

Mr. Trump has been criminally convicted and faces charges of fraud and conspiracy, raising concerns about his adherence to the law. His attempts to evade prosecution and incitement of the January 6 insurrection show a disregard for democratic principles. He has targeted minority groups, issued inflammatory remarks about Australia's ambassador, and faced sexual assault allegations, including a jury finding him liable for abusing writer E. Jean Carroll. His conduct conflicts with Australian values of respect and equality.

We therefore ask the House to exercise its discretion under Section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 and deny Mr. Trump entry to Australia on the basis that his documented behaviour and public influence fail to meet the character expectations set by Australian law.

This request reflects the values upheld by Australians—inclusivity, respect for diversity, and commitment to democratic principles. Allowing entry to individuals who pose a risk to these values would be contrary to our national interests.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6834)
Freedom of Speech
To the Parliament of Australia,
We, the undersigned, express our strong opposition to the proposed Misinformation Bill, which threatens the fundamental principles of freedom of expression and access to information in our democracy.

This bill, while aimed at combating misinformation, raises serious concerns about censorship and the potential for government overreach. The subjective nature of "misinformation" places undue power in the hands of authorities to define and penalize dissenting views, stifling public discourse and debate on critical issues.

Moreover, the bill poses threats to journalists, researchers, and everyday citizens who seek to share information and engage in healthy discussion. The vagueness of the legislation could lead to the silencing of legitimate voices and, ultimately, a less informed society.

History has shown that well-intentioned laws can have unintended consequences that infringe on democratic rights. We urge the government to seek solutions that promote media literacy and critical thinking rather than imposing restrictions that could silence diverse perspectives.

We call on our representatives to oppose the Misinformation Bill, to safeguard our freedom of speech, and to champion a balanced approach to addressing misinformation that fosters open dialogue and accountability.

We therefore ask the House to ask the people of Australia to provide proposals on combating the spread of misinformation rather that resorting to a knee jerk reaction and provide a team of people who can research and gather data supporting this in a natural organic manner which retains the right to free speech.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN6835)
Cybersafety

Both the Government and Opposition have backed the proposal for a blanket prohibition of access to social media for users less than 16 years of age which they argue would be in the best interest of mental health of the youth. Many mental health practitioners, parents, and young people themselves warn however that such a restriction would be, rather than assist, harmful to youth mental health. This policy would undermine a fundamental Australian value: that the government, does not restrict or censor Australian citizens and residents access, but instead provides information, education and assistance.

We therefore ask the House to not implement any social media age restrictions, and instead increase social media safety programs for young people and hold social media companies accountable for what they recommend on their platforms.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN6836)
Cybersafety

A ban on social media for people under 16 could limit our access to educational resources on platforms such as YouTube, could drive us towards unregulated platforms that would harm us more with unsafe content that would be harder to monitor, and many of us, especially marginalised and isolated youth, would lose a big part of our identity and social life. Restricting social media access also infringes on our right to freedom of expression. It is unfair that it is us, not the social media companies, that are receiving punishment for the services that they provide.

We therefore ask the House to oppose the proposed ban on the use of social media by children under 16, and instead promote digital literacy, and hold the social media companies and those that produce harmful content online accountable for their content.
from 92 citizens (Petition No. EN6838)
Cybersafety
We all agree that social media needs to be regulated in Australia.
