However, the Government's proposed age gate for social media sites is not a solution that addresses the core issues of problematic social media use, it won't allocate one cent towards educating children on healthy and safe social media use, it does not protect children from predators or pornography, or punish online predators, it does not give parents a choice in how they raise their own children, it has the potential to give social media companies more access to citizen's sensitive information, and it could potentially position victim-survivors of online sexual exploitation as somehow being responsible for their own abuse.
This is a junk food, non-serious "solution" to a very serious issue and the Parliament should not make it law.
We therefore ask the House to reject the Government's proposed social media age gate and instead pursue comprehensive social media reforms that do not disenfranchise parents and children.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN6839)
Cybersafety

Imposing a social media age limit shifts critical family decisions to the government, eroding parental rights and setting a concerning precedent. Age restrictions risk paving the way for digital ID systems, potentially leading to government monitoring of Australians' online activity. Today, it's age limits; tomorrow, it could be ideological restrictions, threatening freedom of expression, privacy, and the right to dissent.

Instead of restricting access, the government should invest in digital safety education, empowering parents to guide their children online responsibly. Age-based restrictions could lead to further government control, gradually chipping away at individual freedoms. We must act to preserve parental rights, personal privacy, and prevent unwarranted government oversight in Australians' lives.

We therefore ask the House to reject the proposed social media age limit to protect parental rights and prevent unnecessary government control. Parents, not the government, should decide when and how their children access social media. Imposing age restrictions risks opening the door to digital ID systems, which could lead to government monitoring of Australians' online activity and, potentially, restrictions on free expression.

Instead, we urge the House to focus on providing digital safety education and resources for families, allowing parents to guide their children responsibly. Age-based restrictions set a troubling precedent, creating a pathway for broader oversight. We must act now to protect parental rights, individual privacy, and prevent excessive government interference in private lives.
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN6840)
Universities

Boomers who benefited from getting a free degree in the seventies to late eighties should now have made a couple of million dollars to comfortably pay it back. It's not fair to the students of today who have to work harder and have to pay it back sooner when it's harder to get a job due to all the competition. There's more people working and less low skilled jobs available due to technology advancements so securing a job for my generation and the next is going to be incredibly difficult. Even those with degrees find it difficult to get part time jobs or any jobs in their field. Boomers don't need a handout. And they should also pay back their school fees. They aren't cleaners and they don't risk their lives it's the least they can do. They shouldn't be on centelink if they have a degree.
We therefore ask the House to make boomers pay for their degrees
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6845)
Pensions and Benefits

Those who have drivers licences and can work as cleaners shouldn't be on Centrelink it should only be for disabled people or single mothers who are experiencing domestic violence and who are victims of rape and cult brain washing who weren't able to access birth control/ aka not allowed to access their human rights. Public transport should only be for people who have a low iq, and disabled. There should be no stairs on trams because those in wheelchairs and who have prams can't access the tram safety.
We therefore ask the House to ban Centrelink for those who drive and aren't disabled
from one citizen (Petition No. EN6846)
Wages

Teens work to the same capacity as an adult therefore should be allowed to be paid the same for the same job. Not only do they do the job as well as adults they have to commute, go to school, study . Their time and labour is worth just as much as an adult. To deprive them of their money is ageism, discrimination, wage theft, slavery and a hate crime and bullying.
We therefore ask the House to ban junior wages
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN6847)
Visas

Many times we hear about celebrities being granted visas despite being ineligible under Australian law. Being famous is not a sufficient reason to bypass the legislated limitations on eligibility to gain a visa.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that all visa applications are treated equally and that celebrities are not granted visas which non-celebrities with similar eligibility would not be granted.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6851)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Embassy: United States of America

p.span: Australian Embassy: United States of America
The relationship between Australia and the United States of America is one of, if not our most important.

The ambassador plays a vital role in fostering this relationship and having an Ambassador who has publicly and unfairly criticised their former president and now president-elect is completely unacceptable.
We therefore ask the House to step up and do the only thing that is reasonable and replace Kevin Rudd as the Ambassador.

To remain in this post once President Trump takes office is unacceptable, an embarrassment and could potentially harm this important relationship that we have spent blood and tears to foster of the past hundred plus years.
from 46 citizens (Petition No. EN6852)
Cybersafety

Social media may be bad in some ways but it makes an easy way to communicate with long distance friends and family and things like YouTube and TikTok can help in an educational environment as most teachers will make students watch videos in class for their learning. Also some people under 16 make money off things on social media platforms and they might not have other jobs they can do.
We therefore ask the House to not enforce the social media ban or at least let the people effected by it vote for it.
from 588 citizens (Petition No. EN6856)
Workplace Relations

Australian workers are asking to change the terms of casual employment to ensure workers are better protected. We find that the common experience of casual workers in Australia is routinely working full-time hours or more, with no leave entitlements, and being vulnerable to workplace abuse. Due to the inherent insecurity of their contracts, casual employees are necessarily reluctant to raise complaints, because doing so puts them at risk of suddenly losing work. For this reason, we ask that all employment contracts, whether casual or permanent, include guaranteed hours and notice of termination, as the absence of these entitlements enables employers to exploit the threat of job insecurity to impose unreasonable conditions.
We therefore ask the House to —

- Revise the definition of casual employment from being an employment relationship "with no firm advance commitment to ongoing work," to "working up to 20 hours per week with a guarantee of one shift per week at a minimum length of 5 hours."
- Ensure casuals begin receiving overtime after 20 hours in a week, as they are working at least part-time.
- Provide that all employment contracts include a minimum of two weeks notice of termination and provide cause for termination.
- Maintain the casual loading rate in lieu of paid leave entitlements
- Require that no more than 20% of a business' workforce is casual.
from 62 citizens (Petition No. EN6860)
Animal Welfare

It is not regulated anywhere that users must notify neighbours or communities when undertaking a calicivirus release, due to these authorized users such as councils do not have necessary obligation to alert the public of the virus release.

There is also no legislated requirement for areas treated with calicivirus to be closed off from public access, this means that anyone entering these infected areas can bring the virus home and infect their own pet rabbit as it is highly contagious.

The virus is at its strongest in the first 24 hours of release but can persist for a short period of time on clothing and on pet bedding that has been in contact with an infected rabbit or area and through flies and mosquitoes to susceptible rabbits.
There is a vaccination that vaccinates against RHDV 1 and 2 BUT it is 1. not 100% guaranteed and 2. has a hefty cost of $200 per year per rabbit which can be very costly when having multiple rabbits.
Our pet rabbits are loved just as much as we love our pet cats and dogs. What if this virus was killing your cat or dog, would you be ok with not being alerted?
We therefore ask the House to mandate alerts prior to releasing the deadly calicivirus ahead of time so pet owners can assure their rabbits are safe.
2. Help in funding the vaccination for our pets as this is intentionally released.
from 324 citizens (Petition No. EN6862)
Aviation Industry
A secure airline free from pursuit of profits that serve Australian interests and core regional values.
We therefore ask the House to consider nationalising Rex as a not for profit airline.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN6865)
Migration
We respectfully request the House of Representatives to take urgent action to reunite our sibling and family members with us in Australia.

The prolonged separation has caused profound emotional and mental strain on our family. Reuniting families reflects Australia's proud tradition of fostering strong family connections, which are vital to the nation's social and cultural fabric.
Your support for this petition will help our family heal from the pain of separation and contribute to Australia's vibrant and diverse community.
We, the undersigned, urge the House of Representatives to take immediate action to bring families back together.
We therefore ask the House to
1- Review and prioritize the family tourist visa application process, especially for parents and siblings enduring extended separation and seeking safety from conflict zones.
2- Create clearer and more compassionate pathways for family reunification under humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN6871)
Health Care: Maternity Services

Over 7 million Australian's live in rural Australia, contributing over $500 billion to our economy. Yet they are disproportionately impacted by limitations in maternity services. Since the early 1990s, the number of babies born before arrival has increased by 50 per cent nationally. Alarmingly, over half of rural maternity services, or more than 140, have closed since then, placing women and their babies at greater risk of adverse outcomes including mortality and roadside births, and placing increased financial and psychological stress on the woman and her family.

We therefore ask the House to : in the next Budget cycle, to deliver bundled funding across maternity settings and care provider to ensure more equity in funding and service delivery, address any outstanding structural and financial barrier for women to access Endorsed Midwives including Medicare for Homebirth, ensure the funding agreements between the Commonwealth and State and Territory government has provisions for providing maternity services according to the Rural Birthing Index, and ensure national maternity care satisfaction data and experience of the perinatal period is captured through the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.
from 435 citizens (Petition No. EN6873)
Health Care
A strong private health system is essential for the sustainability of Australia's healthcare system.

Private hospitals not only provide critical services and reduce pressure on the public system, but also offer 'competition' to public health services offering patients choice and access to high levels of specialised care.
Without appropriate funding, private hospitals face significant challenges threatening the safety and quality of care they provide.

This situation could also threaten private healthcare generally, risking a collapse in the function and effectiveness of private health insurance. The impact on the public system would be catastrophic.
To ensure that private hospitals can continue to meet the needs of Australians, it is crucial to address the current and ongoing funding gaps—which has forced over 70 private hospitals to close.

This can be achieved not only through public-private partnerships, government incentives, and policies that support both private health insurance and direct funding for private healthcare providers, but also through the fail-safe of an Independent Private Health Commission.

With a well-supported, stable, and fair private hospital system, Australia's healthcare system can continue to deliver safe, efficient, and high-quality care for all citizens through this unique balance.
The Commonwealth Ombudsman already has the responsibility to oversight and resolve issues within private health, but it is clear that this process is not working.
Private health is critically important in Australia. It needs its own Commission and presiding Commissioner.
We therefore ask the House to establish an Independent Private Health Commission.
from 268 citizens (Petition No. EN6877)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
The health minister has claimed on several occasions that Big Tobacco have hooked a whole new generation on vapes yet hasn't taken legal action against Big Tobacco for this!
Why not?
As concerned parents and citizens of Australia we no longer want vapes in the hands of those underage.
We need action NOW! Before it's too late!
Mark Butler's mentor Nicola Roxon and the Australian Government succesfully won big in the courts against Big Tobacco with plain packaging laws, why not with vapes?
It's past time to make Big Tobacco accountable.
Big Tobacco must now be held accountable and the Australian Government should bring them to trial.
We therefore ask the House to take action to charge Big Tobacco under all appropriate laws for trying to hook a whole new underage generation to vapes.
We request Health Minister Mark Butler to explain why he hasn't taken this action already.
We request that Health Minister Mark Butler lead this action against Big Tobacco to put them in the courts and to expedite this action.
from 92 citizens (Petition No. EN6879)
Climate Change
Title: Petition Against Net Zero by 2050—A Call for Pragmatic, Balanced Climate Policy
To: The Australian House of Representatives
From:Concerned Citizen
Date: (20th of November 2024)
Subject: Petition to Reject Net Zero by 2050 and Adopt a More Achievable Emissions Reduction Target of 48% by 2050
Dear Members of the House of Representatives,

I, [Your Full Name], a concerned Australian citizen, submit this petition to express my strong opposition to the Net Zero by 2050 commitment and call for a more balanced emissions reduction target of 48% by 2050.

While addressing climate change is essential, Net Zero by 2050 is unrealistic given Australia's economic and technological landscape. Key industries, including energy, mining, and manufacturing, will be severely impacted by such a rapid transition. Without adequate technological solutions and time for industries to adjust, the policy will lead to job losses and undermine economic stability.

I propose a more achievable target of 48% emissions reduction by 2050, which allows for gradual progress without compromising economic competitiveness. This approach offers time for innovation, industry adaptation, and sustainable job creation, while maintaining fiscal responsibility.
I respectfully urge Members of the House to:
1. Reject Net Zero by 2050 in favor of a 48% reduction target.
2. Prioritize economic stability, job security, and technological feasibility in future climate policies.
3. Support industries in transitioning with adequate time and resources.
A balanced approach to climate action is crucial for Australia's future prosperity, and this petition advocates for a policy that protects both our environment and our economy.
UnderSigned: A Concerned Citizen
We therefore ask the House to Act For Undersigners
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6880)
Age Pension
It should be the right of all Australian citizens and permanent residents to receive the full age pension, subject to their assets and should not be reduced by their partners earnings.
We therefore ask the House to allow all age pensioners to receive a full pension, regardless of what their partner earns instead of the current situation, where it can easily be educed to zero.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN6881)
Health Care

Healthcare is a fundamental human right and should be accessible to all, regardless of citizenship or visa status. In Australia, while some benefit from the publicly funded healthcare system, many individuals still face financial barriers to accessing necessary care. These barriers disproportionately affect those who are not covered by Medicare, including temporary visa holders, asylum seekers, and migrants, who may face high out-of-pocket costs or be denied essential services altogether.

Free healthcare for all people in Australia, regardless of their status, would remove these financial and systemic obstacles, ensuring that everyone has access to the care they need when they need it. This would improve overall health outcomes, reduce preventable illness, and create a more equitable society. By guaranteeing free healthcare for all, we can foster a healthier, more inclusive Australia, where the well-being of every person is prioritized over profit.
We urge the Australian Government to implement a universal, free healthcare system for all people living in Australia, regardless of citizenship or visa status.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Implement a universal healthcare system that provides free access to all medical services for every person residing in Australia, regardless of their citizenship or immigration status.
2. Ensure that healthcare is inclusive of mental health services, emergency care, preventive measures, and other necessary treatments.
3. Work towards dismantling the financial and administrative barriers that prevent people from accessing healthcare based on their status.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6882)
Freedom of Speech

The Australian constitution does not at this time have written anywhere in its entirety a citizens right to freedom of speech or a citizen's right to freedom of the press . Australians citizens deserve the right to these particular freedoms and the mentioned freedoms must be enshrined in the Australian constitution. The governments elected by the Australian people should not have the right to censor the press or dictate the speech of Australian citizens in any manner ! Freedom of Speech must be the basis of the Australian culture! It is the most simple yet powerful of all freedoms and Australians must be allowed it.
We therefore ask the House to
Request by all means necessary to apply Freedom of Speech and Freedom of the Press into the Australian Constitution
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN6888)
Cybersafety

The new media-ban affecting under 16s is quite disastrous. Many teenagers use social media to connect with friends, entertain themselves, or have a break from reality. Some even use social media as their only source of income, either to support themselves or their family. Some use social media as a cry for help. Connecting with others and having someone who can't judge you for your upsetting thoughts can really support your mental health. By taking away social media from teenagers, you are taking away friendships, support, excitement, happiness, and for a lot of people, the only reason they can still enjoy life.

We therefore ask the House to reconsider how the media-ban could affect the younger population of Australia. Forget about the ban, and protect who you still can. In other ways. Taking away the problem is not always a good solution.
from 223 citizens (Petition No. EN6889)
Australia Post

The planned closure of the Artarmon Post Office will leave the community without accessible postal services, forcing residents and businesses to rely on a facility located 1.79 kilometers away. This poses significant challenges, particularly for elderly residents, people with mobility issues, and local businesses that depend on convenient postal services for their operations. The closure risks disrupting the daily lives of the community and diminishing its overall functionality and convenience. Relocating the post office to a nearby site within Artarmon is essential to ensure that residents and businesses continue to have access to these critical services, preserving the integrity and vibrancy of the community. This is why we are urgently requesting action to address this pressing issue.

We therefore ask the House to intervene and work with Australia Post to ensure that the Artarmon Post Office is relocated to a nearby, accessible location within the Artarmon community. This action should be prioritized to maintain essential postal services for residents, businesses, and other stakeholders who rely on them. The goal is to identify and establish an alternative site before or shortly after the planned closure on 12 March 2025, ensuring uninterrupted access to these vital services.
from 1,805 citizens (Petition No. PN0632)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Ministerial Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 58 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4208, which requests the Parliament to enact legislation for mandatory CO2 vehicle emissions standards. I apologise for the delay in responding.

On 28 March 2024, I introduced the New Vehicle Efficiency Standard Bill (the Bill), to implement the Australian Government's preferred model for the New Vehicle Efficiency Standard (the Standard). The Bill was passed by both Houses of Parliament on 16 May 2024 and received Royal Assent on 31 May 2024.

The Standard will provide around $86 billion in net benefits for Australians by 2050, including around $95 billion in fuel cost savings and $5 billion in health benefits. It will also reduce CO2 emissions by around 321 million tonnes by 2050. Without the Standard, transport is projected to become Australia's largest source of emissions by 2030.

Designing the best possible standard to suit Australia's circumstances is complex, and the Government is committed to getting it right. The Government's preferred model was informed by extensive industry and public consultation, detailed economic modelling, and consideration of the unique standards designed for other jurisdictions like New Zealand, the European Union, and the United States.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Housing: Building Standards
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 regarding a petition requesting homeworkers have the ability to install of data cabling for their own internal computer networks (EN4318 refers).

Firstly, I apologise for the delay responding. As you may be aware, this petition was not received by my office until 25 July 2023. I then understand it was assigned to an officer in the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts for investigation, but that officer subsequently left their position without finalising the investigation.

My department has since sought information from the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) as the agency responsible for administering the regulation of telecommunications customer cabling.

The ACMA has advised that the customer cabling regulatory framework is designed to ensure the safety of end users and cablers, as well as protecting the integrity of telecommunication networks. The installation of data cabling (telecommunications customer cabling) concealed within a building cavity can lead to an electrical safety risk if not installed in accordance with the regulations.

However, there are low-risk tasks that can be undertaken by end users (including homeowners) safely without a registered cabler. For example, an end user may install cabling that connects modems, routers and printers to a home computer network—provided that the cabling is not concealed in a building cavity and is connected using customer equipment and cables that comply with applicable technical standards.

A registered cabler will need to be engaged for the installation of any customer cabling in the home that is concealed within a wall, floor or ceiling cavity. The ACMA offers advice on finding a registered cabler on its website acma.gov.au/find-registered-cabler.

The Types of Cabling Work Declaration 2013, which specified what is and what is not considered to be a type of cabling work was due to sunset on 1 April 2024. After public consultation the ACMA made the Telecommunications (Types of Cabling Work) Declaration 2024. The new Declaration largely replicates the previous one, with minor changes to enable end users to perform low-risk tasks in certain circumstances, and to improve clarity. Further information on the new Declaration can be found via acma.gov.au/telecommunications-types-cabling-work-declaration-2024.

ACMA staff can assist the principal petitioner and others if they require any additional information about the regulatory arrangements for customer cabling. Enquiries can be directed to trdsenquiries@acma.gov.au.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Higher Education Loan Program
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding Petition EN5045 on fee changes for higher education psychology courses. I apologise for the delay in responding.

In the 2024-25 Mid-Year Economic Fiscal Outlook, the Albanese Government announced an additional $2.5 billion investment in higher education over the next 10 years. This includes the establishment of the Australian Tertiary Education Commission (ATEC) to lead reform over the longer-term including through implementing Managed Growth and Needs-based Funding to ensure more students can access, participate and succeed in higher education.

The Government also recently announced a series of measures that will provide significant relief for students. This includes a commitment to reduce every Australian's Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) debt by 20 per cent. This will benefit 3 million Australians and will wipe $16 billion in HELP and other student debt. An individual with a HELP debt of $27,600 will see $5,520 removed from their outstanding student loan.

Alongside this, the Government will change the repayment system and increase the amount people can earn before they are required to start repaying their student loan. This means people with a HELP debt will only need to start repaying once they earn $67,000 rather than the current $54,435. It will also reduce the size of repayments per year. For someone on an income of $70,000, this will mean they will pay around $1,300 less per year.

These commitments build on the significant reforms the Albanese Government is already implementing. This includes making the indexation of HELP debts fairer, cost of living relief for students, support for people from the outer suburbs and regions to go to university and structural reforms to our tertiary education system.

The University Accord (Student Support and Other Measures) Bill 2024 that passed the Parliament on 26 November 2024 delivers the first measures in response to reforms recommended by the Universities Accord. This includes capping the HELP indexation rate to the lower of either the Consumer Price Index (CPI) or the Wage Price Index (WPI), establishing for the first time a new Commonwealth Prac Payment for those studying teaching, nursing, midwifery and social work, and massively expanding FEE-FREE Uni Ready courses.

The change to HELP indexation applies retrospectively from 1 June 2023 and will benefit all Australians with a student loan. It will fix the issue of last year's spike in the CPI indexation rate of 7.1 per cent and will prevent growth in student debt from outpacing wages growth in the future. These changes apply to all HELP, vocational education and training Student Loan, Australian Apprenticeship Support Loan and other student loan accounts.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) started processing indexation credits in December 2024, which will be for the difference between the indexation rates that applied in 2023 and 2024 and the updated indexation rates. This will provide relief for students while continuing to protect the integrity and value of the HELP system, which has massively expanded higher education access for millions of Australians. For an individual with an average HELP debt of $26,500, around $1,200 will be wiped from their outstanding student loan.

Further information on how announced changes may benefit those with a HELP debt is available using the HELP debt reduction and repayment estimators at www.education.gov.au/higher-education-loan-program/20-reduction-student-loan-debt.

The new Commonwealth Prac Payment will be available from 1 July 2025 and is expected to support around 68,000 eligible 1teaching, nursing, midwifery and social work students in higher education to complete their practical training each year.

FEE-FREE Uni Ready courses are free courses that effectively provide a bridge between school and university. They give students who need them the foundational skills to succeed at university. Our amendments provide a massive expansion of these important, life changing courses from 1 January 2025.

I acknowledge the issues raised in Petition EN5045 regarding funding for psychology courses. The Government is committed to improving the mental health and wellbeing of all Australians. As announced in the 2023-24 Budget, we have invested $91.3 million to address acute bottlenecks in the psychology training pipeline. This includes incentives for universities to create 500 additional postgraduate psychology places in relevant areas of endorsed practice.

Funding arrangements for psychology courses were set by the previous government through their Job-ready Graduate scheme. Their changes decreased base funding for postgraduate psychology and significantly increased student fees for Commonwealth supported students studying Organisational Psychology and relevant courses leading to general registration.

The Universities Accord made several recommendations relating to the previous government's Job-ready Graduates scheme, including that student contributions for Commonwealth supported students studying humanities, communications, other society and culture, and human movement1 units should be reduced, and that student contributions should move toward a system based on projected potential lifetime earnings of graduates.

As I've said in the Parliament, the Accord is a plan not for one budget, but a blueprint for the next decade to help us build a better and fairer education system. Further consideration will be given to other Accord recommendations in future budget processes and based on advice from the ATEC regarding higher education pricing matters, once it is established.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Meat and Livestock Industry
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence dated 1 August 2023, to the former Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator the Hon Murray Watt, concerning Petition EN5162—ban on the synthetic meat trade. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The red meat industry remains an integral part of the Australian agriculture sector and a key contributor to our nation's economic prosperity. The Australian Government continues to work closely with the industry towards greater trade, animal welfare and sustainability outcomes and acknowledges its essential role in meeting the Australian agriculture sector's goal of agricultural production being valued at $100 billion by 2030.

The government believes there is room for industries producing both traditional and emerging sources of protein to thrive. This will be essential as we look to meet the increasing protein demands of a growing global population. The Australian cell-cultured food industry is emerging and is primarily in the research and development phase. Research by CSIRO has identified a $13 billion market opportunity for Australia to grow and diversify its high-quality protein products from various sources.

Current regulatory arrangements and principles are effective at protecting the environment and the health of Australians. In Australia, the regulatory approval of sale of novel foods, including cell-cultured meat, is managed by Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ), the independent food standard setting agency for the joint Australia New Zealand food regulation system. Existing regulatory arrangements prevent food being sold in Australia—including imported food—that does not meet the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Code).

There are currently no cell-cultured meats available for consumption in Australia. The first application for cell-cultured quail is currently under consideration by FSANZ. This application is classified as a 'Major Procedure' requiring two rounds of public consultation. FSANZ completed the first round of public consultation on this work in February 2024.

Following consideration of submitter feedback and available evidence FSANZ prepared a draft variation to the Code. The second round of consultation on draft regulatory measures is now underway via FSANZ's Consultation Hub at consultations.foodstandards.qov.au. Consultation closes on 24 December 2024. I encourage the public to engage in this consultation.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Ms Collins
Taxation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5368 on removing the automatic excise tax increases on alcohol.

Biannual indexation in accordance with the Consumer Price Index is a longstanding feature of the alcohol tax system. It ensures that alcohol excise amounts keep pace with inflation and that the tax component of alcoholic beverages remains broadly stable as a proportion of their total price. Without biannual indexation, the real value of alcohol excise would fall over time as alcohol prices rise in line with inflation.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 18 March 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN5916, with 5,338 signatures, concerning an allegation of poisoning at Tsinghua University, China in 1994. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government takes very seriously its role in protecting the community from unacceptable risk of harm from criminal or other serious conduct by non-citizens. Everyone who wishes to enter or stay in Australia must satisfy the character requirement as set out in section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act).

A person may not pass the character test on a number of grounds, including but not limited to if they have a substantial criminal record, or if there is a risk that they may engage in criminal conduct, vilify, incite discord in, or represent a danger to, the Australian community or a segment of the Australian community.

If the community has specific information in relation to persons of character concern, immigration fraud or any suspicious border-related behaviour, they can report the matter to the Border Watch via https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/departmental-forms/online-forms/border-watch.

Please be assured that any information provided by members of the public is treated in the strictest of confidence. Due to privacy considerations, no information can be provided on the progress or outcome of any investigation.
Please be assured, all non-citizens must meet, and continue to meet, the requirements set out in the Act, including identity, security, health and character requirements.

Decisions on visa applications are made only after full and careful consideration and in accordance with Australia's migration legislation. Under the migration legislation, the delegate is compelled to refuse an application if they are not satisfied that the applicant meets the prescribed criteria for a visa.

If a visa holder fails to comply with their visa conditions, engages in criminal activity or other behaviour of concern, or there is evidence that they have provided false or misleading information in their visa application, their visa will be considered for cancellation.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5916 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 14 May 2024 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP enclosing Petition EN5942, with 1163 signatures, concerning the Government's decision to cap and cease the Skilled—Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visa, as announced in the Migration Strategy. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Migration Strategy released on 11 December 2023 outlined the Government's vision for recalibrating student and graduate visa settings to support both the education sector and Australia's migration needs, while simplifying Australia's migration system.

Changes from the Migration Strategy will ensure Australia attracts and retains the skilled workers it needs while addressing the number of 'permanently temporary' visa holders under previous arrangements. The Government recognises the valuable contributions which migrants have made, including injecting valuable skills into our labour market and enriching our communities.

The Skilled—Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visa was capped on 22 December 2023 and closed permanently on 1 July 2024. The Migration Strategy confirmed the visa no longer aligned with policy priorities, added to the complexity of the migration system and recognised that internationally trained engineers could apply for other visas that allow them to work or migrate to Australia.
All undecided Skilled-Recognised Graduate visa applications were administratively finalised and affected visa applicants were advised to apply for a repayment of their Visa Application Charge.

To investigate alternate options available for internationally trained engineers, applicants can visit the visa finder on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5942 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Tertiary Education: Unpaid Clinical Placement
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding Petition EN5988, in relation to expansion of the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) debt reduction program to include all health workers completing unpaid clinical placements. I apologise for the delay in responding.

In the 2024-25 Mid-Year Economic Fiscal Outlook, the Albanese Government announced an additional $2.5 billion investment in higher education over the next 10 years. This includes the establishment of the Australian Tertiary Education Commission (ATEC) to lead reform over the longer-term including through implementing Managed Growth and Needs-based Funding to ensure more students can access, participate and succeed in higher education.

The Government also recently announced a series of measures that will provide significant relief for students. This includes a commitment to reduce every Australian's HELP debt by 20 per cent. This will benefit 3 million Australians and will wipe $16 billion in HELP and other student debt. An individual with a HELP debt of $27,600 will see $5,520 removed from their outstanding student loan.

Alongside this, the Government will change the repayment system and increase the amount people can earn before they are required to start repaying their student loan. This means people with a HELP debt will only need to start repaying once they earn $67,000 rather than the current $54,435. It will also reduce the size of repayments per year. For someone on an income of $70,000, this will mean they will pay around $1,300 less per year.

These commitments build on the significant reforms the Albanese Government is already implementing. This includes making the indexation of HELP debts fairer, cost of living relief for students, support for people from the outer suburbs and regions to go to university and structural reforms to our tertiary education system.

The University Accord (Student Support and Other Measures) Bill 2024 that passed the Parliament on 26 November 2024 delivers the first measures in response to reforms recommended by the Universities Accord. This includes capping the HELP indexation rate to the lower of either the Consumer Price Index (CPI) or the Wage Price Index (WPI), establishing for the first time a new Commonwealth Prac Payment for those studying teaching, nursing, midwifery and social work, and massively expanding FEE-FREE Uni Ready courses.

The change to HELP indexation applies retrospectively from 1 June 2023 and will benefit all Australians with a student loan. It will fix the issue of last year's spike in the CPI indexation rate of 7.1 per cent and will prevent growth in student debt from outpacing wages growth in the future. These changes apply to all HELP, vocational education and training Student Loan, Australian Apprenticeship Support Loan and other student loan accounts.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) started processing indexation credits in December 2024, which will be for the difference between the indexation rates that applied in 2023 and 2024 and the updated indexation rates. This will provide relief for students while continuing to protect the integrity and value of the HELP system, which has massively expanded higher education access for millions of Australians. For an individual with an average HELP debt of $26,500, around $1,200 will be wiped from their outstanding student loan.

Further information on how announced changes may benefit those with a HELP debt is available using the HELP debt reduction and repayment estimators at www.education.gov.au/higher-education-loan-program/20-reduction-student-loan-debt.

The new Commonwealth Prac Payment will be available from 1 July 2025 and is expected to support around 68,000 eligible teaching, nursing, midwifery and social work students in higher education to complete their practical training each year.
Placements are an important part of qualifications for a range of professions that ensure graduates have the skills and experience to enter the workforce and translate learned theory into practice.

The Albanese Government understands that placements can impact a student's financial wellbeing and appreciates the challenges many students experience with meeting the cost of living while studying and completing mandatory placements.

This is the first time the Government has provided financial support for mandatory placements. We are starting with students studying nursing, midwifery, teaching, and social work as recommended by the Australian Universities Accord.

As I have said, the Accord is not a plan for one budget, but a blueprint for the next decade and beyond. Consideration is being given to other recommendations in the Accord, including that the Government work with tertiary education providers, state and territory governments, industry, business and unions to consider further support by employers (public and private) to mitigate the risk of financial hardship and placement poverty for students in other fields.

The Government has also increased support available to students through Austudy, ABSTUDY, Youth Allowance and provided access to more Government Rent Assistance as part of the 2023-24 Budget. These payments support Australians of all ages to attend university to pursue their career ambitions.

I acknowledge the request to include other health related courses in HELP debt reduction programs. The Government has already implemented measures to reduce outstanding HELP debts of teachers, including early childhood teachers, who have completed four years working in very remote Australia. A similar measure has been implemented for eligible doctors and nurse practitioners who live and work in rural, regional or very remote areas of Australia.

Independent reviews of the doctors and nurses HELP reduction initiative will be undertaken in 2025 and in 2028. These reviews will consider expansion of HELP reduction initiatives to other sectors of high skills experiencing similar workforce challenges. The Government will evaluate the effectiveness of the program and may consider any recommendations to expand these measures to other sectors in future budget processes.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024

p.span: Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN6091, with 4,543 signatures, concerning the proposed Migration Amendment (Removal and Other Measures) Bill 2024 (the Bill). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia has a long history of generous migration and humanitarian resettlement programs. Our migration framework underpins these programs and ensures that those who have a right to enter and remain in Australia are afforded that right and opportunity. This framework also relies on the Australian Government having the ability to remove non-citizens once they no longer have a lawful right to remain in Australia.
Australia makes every effort to cooperate with countries on the return of their nationals to their home country when they have exhausted all avenues to remain in Australia.

The powers in this Bill to designate a removal concern country recognise that there may be some countries that obstruct or do not facilitate the return of their own citizens from Australia. The Government understands the serious nature of this designation, and the making of such a designation would only be considered following significant Government to Government engagement on the issues and challenges of returns, and where doing so is in Australia's national interest.

Importantly, the Bill allows for the power to be exercised in a flexible and scalable way, and contains appropriate exemptions, for example, for close relatives of Australian citizens or permanent residents and for offshore humanitarian entrants.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6091 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Tertiary Education: Migration Law
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 July 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP enclosing Petition EN6250, with 99 signatures, concerning the requirement for prospective Registered Migration Agents (RMAs) to complete the Capstone Assessment (the Capstone). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention and have passed on the feedback in the Petition to the Office of the Migration Agents Registration Authority.

In order to be eligible for registration as an RMA under the Migration Act 1958 (Migration Act), a person must first complete a prescribed qualification (being a Graduate Diploma or Master degree) offered by specified education providers. Under the Migration Agents Regulations 1998, the Minister may also prescribe an examination for the purposes of satisfying vocational requirements under the Migration Act. The Migration (IMMI 18/003: Specified courses and exams for registration as a migration agent) Instrument 2018 prescribes the Capstone as this examination, requiring an RMA to pass the examination before being registered.

I acknowledge that the Capstone contributes to the time and effort required to become an RMA, and that the nature of examinations can be stressful. I also recognise that satisfying the qualification and examination requirements require significant financial investment. However, in light of the important service that RMAs provide in supporting potentially vulnerable migrants to navigate the complexities of our migration system, it is essential that new RMAs are well prepared.

The Capstone was introduced in July 2018, following a finding by the I (the Kendall Review). The Kendall Review found that existing entry requirements for prospective RMAs were inadequate, and did not properly prepare agents for practice. The Capstone ensures that all prospective RMAs have a deep knowledge of migration law and procedure prior to entering the industry. The examination is standardised, meaning all prospective RMAs are assessed by the same criteria, regardless of when or where they completed their prescribed qualification.

I draw your attention to recent changes in the delivery of the Capstone, which have had a positive impact on the success rate amongst candidates. This includes a consolidation of the written assessments, and an expanded oral test component. The implementation of these changes from October 2023 resulted in a 61 percent pass rate for the October 2023 intake, compared to 44 percent for the July 2023 intake.
The changes also resulted in a reduced fee for the Capstone—from $2,690.00 to $2,156.00.

I note the Petition expresses concerns about the fee charged for the Capstone. While the Migration (Specified courses and exams for registration as a migration agent) (Capstone provider) Amendment Instrument (LIN 21/044) 2021 nominates Legal Training Australia (LT A) as the provider of the Capstone, the instrument does not specify the fee to be charged for exam candidates. The fee is determined and charged by the LTA.

Lastly, you may be aware that the Department has undertaken to remake a number of legislative instruments in the RMA regulatory framework, prior to their forthcoming sunset in April 2026. This will include the remake of legislation relevant to the prescribed examination. I will ensure the feedback from the petition is considered in this process.
Thank you again for bringing Petition EN6250 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Bharatiya Janata Party
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 August 2024 enclosing Petition EN6377, with 204 signatures, concerning alleged activities and influence of the Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) and associated groups in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Espionage and foreign interference threaten the things we value most about our country- our social cohesion, our trusted democracy, and our freedom of expression. It is unacceptable for any foreign government to target members of our community in ways that prevent individuals exercising their fundamental rights and freedoms in Australia.

The Australian Government has criminal offences and a robust framework in place to protect our democracy from acts of foreign interference and strengthen our resilience. These legislative measures support Australia's security and, law enforcement agencies to discover, deter and disrupt acts of foreign interference.

The Government is investing $71.6 million over four years from 2024-2025 to bolster our counter foreign interference efforts to protect Australians. This includes $30.7 million over the next four years and $7.8 million per year ongoing to the Countering Foreign Interference Taskforce, which works to identify, assess, investigate and disrupt acts of foreign interference.
Reports of foreign interference activity can be made to the National Security Hotline:
If an interpreter is required, the Translating and Interpreting Service can be called on 131 450 who will call the National Security Hotline.
Email: hotline@nationalsecurity.gov.au
Reports made to the National Security Hotline can be made anonymously, and are passed to the appropriate law enforcement and security agencies for consideration.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6377 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Burke
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Chair

Thank you for bringing to my attention the signed petition (EN6395) presented to the House of Representatives on 8 October 2024. This petition has requested a variety of changes to better respond to cases of family and domestic violence.

The Australian Government is committed to ongoing improvements to the family law system and providing the best possible outcomes for family and children, and is progressing a range of reforms and policy changes that are relevant to the concerns raised by this petition.
Each part of the petition request has been addressed below:

On 6 September 2024, National Cabinet agreed to a $4.7 billion package to support legal services and accelerate action to deliver on Australia's National Plan to End Violence Against Women and Children 2022-2032 (National Plan), which sets out the long-term vision to end violence in one generation. This package includes innovative approaches to better identify and respond to high risk and serial perpetrators of family violence. Models to intervene in high-risk and se1ial family violence offending, will be developed and delivered in partnership with States and Territories and non-government stakeholders, with the aim of reducing homicide rates.

All governments also agreed to work together to develop a shared understanding of what constitutes a serial or high-risk family violence offender and explore enhancements to the National Criminal Intelligence System to alert police nationwide to people who meet these criteria.
In addition, to ensure people who use violence are held to account and support them to change their behaviours, the Government delivers the following initiatives:

No To Violence's National Perpetrator Intervention and Referral Service provides direct telephone and online suppo1t to men who are using violent or controlling behaviour, including men who may be waiting to access a Behaviour Change Program.

MensLine Australia (MLA) services, which include a national telephone line and online support, information and referral service for men with family and relationship concerns, including men experiencing domestic violence.

MensLine Changing for Good is a free multi-session phone counselling service for men who want to develop healthy and respectful relationships with the people in their life, and help men to continue to have violence-free relationships.
A national early intervention trial for young men and adolescent boys who are at risk of perpetrating family, domestic and sexual violence to prevent them from using violence.
A partnership with states and territories to apply innovative approaches to address the behaviour of people who use family, domestic or sexual violence.

span.span: 2. AVO and Parenting Orders be in Sync with each
other (Local Court & Family Court work in collab currently their judgements contradict heavily)

p.span: Family law courts are required to ensure, to the greatest extent possible, that any parenting order it makes is consistent with existing family violence orders and does not expose a person to an unacceptable risk of family violence. The order may include any measures that the court considers necessary to ensure the safety of those affected by the order.

On 4 June 2024, the Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs adopted an inquiry into family violence orders (FVOs). The terms of reference outline that the inquiry will have regard to matters such as the current barriers for litigants in the family law system to obtain and enforce FVOs, including the intersection between FVOs and parenting orders, and that a family court parenting order may override an FVO, as well as how FVOs could be more accessible for victims of violence going through the family law system.
Details about the inquiry are available online:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentaiy_Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal_Affairs/Familyviolenceorders.

In addition, the Australian Government has taken a leadership role in ensuring that protections under Domestic Violence Orders (DVOs) can be recognised and enforced across Australia. The National Domestic Violence Order Scheme (NDVOS) is a model law statutory scheme under which States and Territories automatically recognise and enforce one another's DVOs. It is currently underpinned by an interim information-sharing solution that leverages the National Police Reference System (managed by the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission) to provide police and courts with information on DVOs issued across Australia. The NDVOS and the interim system help improve police situational awareness when responding to domestic violence incidents, improving both victim and police safety, and ensure local courts can recognise, amend and othe1wise effectively deal with DVOs, even if issued interstate. The Attorney-General's Department is also currently progressing a review of family and domestic violence order frameworks.

span.span: 3. Stop the misuse of Mental Health Act

Cancel the license of Doctors / Physiologists if fake documents are produced in the court to defend the offender of criminal proceedings. No history of mental health and suddenly if the offender is suffering from mental health means documents are fake

p.span: Responsibility for the mental health and suicide prevention system is shared between the Commonwealth and States and Territories. Specialist public mental health services, including hospital services, are the responsibility of States and Territories. States and Territories are also responsible for establishing and administering their respective mental health and suicide prevention legislation, meaning each jurisdiction has its own Mental Health Act.

Registered health practitioners under the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law, including medical practitioners and psychologists, are subject to professional codes of conduct. If an individual believes or is concerned that a registered health practitioner is not complying with their code of conduct they can make a complaint to the Australian Health Practitioner Registration Agency (Ahpra). Ahpra and the relevant National Board will consider their concerns and decide on an appropriate course of action to take in the interest of public safety. If a health practitioner does not meet expected standards, Ahpra and the National Board can take regulatory action, including applying conditions to a practitioner's practise or suspending registration. Further information on how to submit a concern is available on Ahpra's website at: www.ahpra.gov.au/Notifications/Concerned-about-a-health-practitioner.aspx.
These actions can occur concurrently with criminal proceedings imposed by the court.
Ahpra is currently undertaking work to increase the skills and knowledge of registered health practitioners in family domestic and sexual violence.

span.span: 4. Sole Parental responsibility and child custody to offender's Partner

p.span: The 'best interests of the child' is the paramount consideration when a court makes an order in parenting matters, including in relation to who has parental responsibility for the child and with whom a child should live. This includes consideration of what parenting arrangements would promote the safety of children and their caregivers, and the benefit to the child of having a relationship with their parents and other people significant to their care, welfare and development.

In addition, when making parenting orders, the court must consider any incidence of family violence or family violence order concerning the child or a member of the child's family. When applying to the court for parenting orders, parties are required to disclose child abuse and family violence by completing a 'notice of child abuse, family violence or risk' form. The court is required to take prompt action in relation to allegations of child abuse or family violence. The Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia must report suspected or alleged child abuse to the relevant child welfare authority for assessment, including information that may assist with investigation.

span.span: 5. No social security payment to offender

p.span: Australia's social security system is a non-contributory system designed to support the basic living standards of all eligible Australians. It is a means tested, residence-based system, designed to provide income support to people who, for reasons such as age, unemployment or ill health, are unable to support themselves.

Should the offender be in gaol, under the Social Security Act 1991 social security pensions or benefits are not payable to a person who is in gaol. A person is in gaol if they are lawfully detained while under sentence for a conviction or are in custody pending trial or sentencing. People who are not in custody and waiting trial (on bail) may be paid if they meet eligibility requirements and if applicable, meet mutual obligation requirements. It is not within the legislation to deny payment to an eligible person who has been released from goal.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that the needs of women and children experiencing family and domestic violence are taken into account in the delivery of government services. Alongside the comprehensive package of measures announced following National Cabinet on 6 September 2024 to accelerate action to end gender-based violence, the Government announced it would commence an audit of key Commonwealth government systems to identify ways perpetrators of family and domestic violence are exploiting them to abuse victim-survivors.

span.span: 6. Lifelong Supervised Visit with Kids until they turn 18+

p.span: As referred to above, a primary consideration in Australia's family law framework is supporting the best interests of the child. The law supports children of separated parents having an ongoing relationship with parents and significant others where it is safe to do so. However, not all families are able to manage this without assistance.

Children's Contact Services (CCS) provide supervised visits or supervised change-over services to families who need additional support to maintain contact. These services may either be government funded or private fee-for-service arrangements. Courts may currently refer families to CCS to support contact between a parent (or other significant person) and a child where there are concerns that this may not be achieved safely without assistance. Families may also currently elect to use CCS of their own volition.

The goal of government-funded CCS is to support families to move towards self-management arrangements where this is safe. There are no standards for how long a family should remain using CCS before service is terminated or the family is able to effectively manage their own arrangements without assistance. In government-funded services, periods of service can vary significantly, but tend to range from 6-12 months depending on local demand and a range of other circumstances.

span.span: 7. Strict rules to protect kids from mental distress & trauma

p.span: The Australian Government acknowledges that exposure to family, domestic and sexual violence can negatively impact the mental health and wellbeing of children and young people. As part of its broader work to address the drivers of distress for children, young people and their families, the Government is supporting the implementation of:

Safe and Supported: The National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children 2021-2031, led by the Minister for Social Services, to ensure that children and young people reach their full potential by growing up safe and supported, free from harm and neglect

the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse 2021-2030, implementation of which is being led by the National Office for Child Safety within the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Depa1iment, which aims to reduce the risk, extent and impact of child sexual abuse and related harms in Australia. This includes the promotion and implementation of the National Principles for Child Safe Organisations (National Principles).

The National Principles are 10 high-level principles that set out a national approach to creating organisational cultures and practices that promote the safety and wellbeing of children in Australia. Each state and territ01y is responsible for implementing the National Principles (or equivalent standards) within their jurisdiction and may have specific requirements for organisations working with children and young people.

Further, one of the measures to support the National Plan, implemented by the Department of Health and Aged Care, is an investment of $48.7 million over four years from 2022-23 to 2025-26 to provide increased support to primary care providers to assist in the early identification and intervention of family, domestic, sexual violence and child sexual abuse.

This is an important step in ensuring that the role of primary care is supported recognising that primary care is often the first point of contact for victim-survivors of family, domestic and sexual violence including for children, young people and their families.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Sponsored Parent Visas
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6420, with 121 signatures, concerning the Sponsored Parent (Temporary) visa (SPTV) (subclass 870) requirements. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The SPTV is a temporary visa, which allows a parent of an Australian citizen, Australian permanent resident or eligible New Zealand citizen to visit Australia for up to three or five years at one time without having to depart Australia. The visa application requirements and visa settings reflect the temporary nature of the visa. This visa does not lead to permanent residence.

SPTV visa applicants must be outside Australia at the time of visa application lodgement, unless applicants have received permission to apply in Australia. Permission to apply in Australia may be approved in exceptional circumstances, including where a parent is unable to depart Australia due to an accident or illness.

A person who holds, or has held, a SPTV and has resided in Australia on that visa can apply for a further SPTV, if they have been outside of Australia for at least 90 consecutive days since the date of their relevant departure from Australia. They must also have a new sponsorship application approved. A person can stay in Australia on multiple SPTVs for a combined maximum period of up to 10 years.
Further information on the SPTV and requests for Permission to Apply in Australia is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/sponsored-parent-temporary-870#aboutVisa-index-7.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6420 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Advocacy for Men
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email to the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, the Prime Minister dated 8 October 2024 regarding petition number EN6428, which requests the House to appoint a Minister for Men and Boys. The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.
I note that the Governor-General appoints Ministers on the advice of the Prime Minister, rather than the House, and I am responding on that basis.

It is a decision of the Prime Minister as to what ministerial portfolios he recommends to the Governor-General as part of the Government. Among these is typically a Minister for Women, which has existed in various forms in governments going back to the first Hawke Government in 1983.

The Government recognises that women face significant social and economic challenges, and continue to be disproportionately impacted by family, domestic and sexual violence. Sixty-four women reportedly lost their lives as a result of violence in Australia in 2023 and 66 women have lost their lives since 1 January 2024. Rates of violence are even higher for First Nations women, women with disability, migrant and refugee women, LGBTIQ+ people and other minority and marginalised groups. Women also experience tech-based abuse more frequently than men and the abuse is often more severe in its nature and damaging in its psychological impact, leaving women twice as likely to fear for their safety compared to men.

Insights to economic challenges faced by Australian women are enabled by longitudinal data. The Government has published a snapshot of this data in the 2024 Status of Women Report Card, which can be accessed via the Australian Government's gender equality strategy website (https://genderequality.gov.au/status-women-report-cards/2024-report-card).

The latest remuneration average gender pay gap provided by the Workplace Gender Equality Agency (WGEA) is 21.8 per cent, with women earning 78 cents for every dollar men earn. This equates to women earning, on average, $28,245 less each year.

The most recent data at the time of writing from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), shows that women spend nine hours a week more than their male counterparts on unpaid work and care. This impacts their lifelong economic security by limiting their labour force participation, career progression, and leadership opportunities.

Additional data from WGEA and the ABS consistently shows that women are overrepresented in lower paid, more casualised sectors, including early childhood care and education, aged and disability care, and underrepresented in higher paid sectors, such as mining and engineering. Women are also underrepresented in leadership and decision-making roles, and are more likely to retire with lower superannuation balances than men.

The challenges that women face in working the hours and jobs they want also impacts the health and wellbeing of men and boys and addressing these challenges benefits men and boys. This work will support men to become more active parents, more highly engaged in home and family life, work flexibly, access paid parental leave and take on greater caring roles.
These challenges require concerted and coordinated whole-of-government policy responses to successfully address, led by a dedicated Minister for Women.

The Government acknowledges that men and boys face specific issues, particularly in relation to mental health and suicide. The Government considers that these can be better addressed by targeted policies and programs, rather than a dedicated Minister for Men. In particular, the Government's framework for men's health is the National Men's Health Strategy 2020-2030. The Strategy includes five priority health issues: mental health and wellbeing, chronic conditions, sexual and reproductive health and conditions, injuries and risk-taking behaviours, and healthy ageing. The Strategy is guided by three key objectives:
empower and support men and boys to optimise their own and each other's health and for wellbeing
build the evidence base for improving men's health
strengthen the capacity of the health system to provide quality appropriate care for men and boys.
Dedicated programs for men's health include:

the Male Health Initiative (MHI)—$18.5 million (GST inclusive) in Australian Government funding has been provided over 10 years (2016-17 to 2025-26) to three organisations: Healthy Male, the Australian Men's Health Forum, and the Centre for Male Health (based at Western Sydney University). MHI funding supports these male health organisations with their core work of maintaining information and awareness on key health issues for Australian males.

the National Suicide Prevention Leadership and Support Program—the Government is investing approximately $17.5 million over three years (2022-23 to 2024-25) for the following activities to support the wellbeing of
The Men's Table, which aims to promote men's mental, emotional and social wellbeing through social connection and support
MATES In Construction, which aims to improve resilience through working with men on the causes of distress, the value of support at work and how to seek help
Parents Beyond Breakup, for their Dads in Distress program which provides support to men who are in distress following a relationship breakdown.

the Healthy Masculinities Trial and Evaluation—$3.5 million provided to explore what works best to counteract the harmful impacts of social media messaging targeting young men and boys, and instead to promote a sense of respect and build healthy relationships with peers and partners.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Senior Australians
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter dated 8 October 2024, to the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, Prime Minister, regarding Petition EN6454, which requests the House of Representatives to call on the Prime Minister to establish a Minister for Older Australians. The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

The Government recognises the important role older Australians play in our community. In addition to the Hon Mark Butler MP, Minister for Health and Aged Care and the Hon Anika Wells MP, Minister for Aged Care, the Prime Minister recently appointed the Hon Kate Thwaites MP, as the Assistant Minister for Ageing, to ensure there is adequate representation in the Ministry on this matter.

While the Government acknowledges the importance of the matters raised in this petition, it has not considered that establishing an additional Minister for Older Australians is necessary. The current Ministry appointments for the Health and Aged Care portfolio and Cabinet arrangements ensure that matters concerning older Australians are effectively represented and coordinated.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6456, with 298 signatures, concerning the processing of Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa applications. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Immigration provides our businesses with the skills they need, stimulates demand for goods and services, and increases our economic output. I am committed to maintaining strong borders and delivering an orderly and compassionate immigration strategy that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

The Australian Government released the Migration Strategy ("the Strategy") in December last year. A key objective of the Strategy is building stronger Australian communities by better planning the migration intake. This will better connect skilled migrants to Australia's skill needs, helping to reignite productivity growth, which will ensure rising living standards, business growth and better wages.

Reducing the number of on-hand visa applications, including in the subclass 191 caseload, has been a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs has been undertaking a range of measures to reduce the processing times for this type of application, and additional resources have been assigned to the caseload.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to government policy priorities, as outlined in Ministerial Direction 105. Under the Ministerial Direction, for applications which are not employer sponsored and in relation to an occupation to be carried out in a designated regional area, the highest priority is being afforded to those visa applications made in relation to healthcare or teaching occupations. Subclass 191 visa applications that are not made in relation to these specific occupations are given lower priority, and these applications are generally processed in the order in which they were received.

Each application is unique and is required to meet the eligibility criteria contained in Australia's migration legislation, before a visa can be granted. The time taken to process an application varies depending on a range of circumstances, such as the complexity of the application and whether additional checks and further assessment are required. Some delays in processing are experienced due to character and security checks, along with verification of an applicant's claims.

More detail regarding visa requirements, processing priorities for skilled visa applications and processing timeframes is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website. Currently, 90 per cent of subclass 191 visas are processed within eight months, which is consistent with the processing times for other general skilled migration visa applications. The Department continues to process these applications efficiently, with the intention to further reduce the total number on-hand.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6456 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6463, with 531 signatures, concerning immigration health examinations required for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

I acknowledge the petitioners' concerns related to costs associated with immigration, health examinations. Before a visa can be granted, each applicant must meet all of the legislative criteria for the visa, including the health requirement.
