The purpose of the health requirement is to protect the Australian community from threats to public health, contain public expenditure on health and community services, and safeguard the access of Australian residents to health and other community services in short supply.

There are special health arrangements in place for those who hold or previously held (within the _last 12 months) a substantive temporary or provisional visa, and then apply for the corresponding permanent visa. Applicants who received a permanent health clearance for their Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visa are not ordinarily required to undertake any additional health checks for their subclass 191 visa application. This is in line with a health policy decision to exempt applicants from undertaking additional health screening at the permanent visa stage (the second stage) where they have completed all the required examinations at the provisional visa stage (the first stage), unless in the following situations:

Where the visa processing officer has reason to believe that the applicant failed to disclose a health condition at the first stage, or there are concerns that fraud may have been involved, or if the Department has information the applicant's health condition has changed since the first stage;
Where the applicant's temporary or provisional visa ceased more than 12 months prior to the delegate commencing assessment of the associated permanent visa;
Where the applicant remained in a higher TB-risk country for more than 18 months after their previous health clearance at the first stage;
Where the applicant subsequently advises of their pregnancy and intention to give birth in Australia;
Where an applicant reaches an age milestone at the time of the second stage processing and is required to undergo additional exams;
Children who have not completed any health exams at the first stage, and are being included as a dependent child on the permanent visa, will be required to complete at the second stage; and

From 1 July 2024, applicants aged 15 years or older applying for a subclass 191 visa that are born in a 'high risk' hepatitis B country will be required to undertake screening for hepatitis Bas part of the Immigration Medical Examinations.

Applicants will be advised by their visa processing officer if they need to complete further health examinations after they have applied for the subclass 191 visa and their individual circumstances have been assessed. More Information on health examinations is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our-requirements/health.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6463 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Universities
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN6508 on indexation of study fee loans.

The Government has heard a range of public concerns about student debts and current indexation and repayment arrangements. In response, the Government has announced a suite of changes to the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) and student loans system. These changes will make the operation of student loans simpler and fairer and reduce the outstanding debt of the 3 million Australians with a student loan by a total of around $19 billion.

In the 2024-25 Budget the Government announced that HELP loans will be indexed at the lower of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) or the Wage Price Index (WPI). The change was backdated to 1 June 2023, lowering the indexation applied to student loans from 7.1 per cent to 3.2 per cent in 2023 and from 4.7 per cent to 4 per cent in 2024. These changes have now been legislated and the Australian Tax Office will automatically apply these changes to people's outstanding debts in the coming weeks.

On 2 November 2024, the Government also announced that it would apply a one-off 20 per cent reduction to all student debts. This will apply to individuals' outstanding debts before annual indexation is applied on 1 June 2025. In addition, from 1 July 2025, repayments of student loans will be made simpler and fairer, with the minimum income threshold for compulsory repayment increasing from $54,435 in 2024-25 to $67,000 in 2025-26, and the introduction of a system where repayments are calculated only on the income above the new $67,000 threshold, rather than repayments being based on total annual income. Under this new marginal repayment model no one will have to pay more than the current system, and every person earning under $180,000 will see a reduction in compulsory repayments.
To find out more about the Government's changes to student loans, visit:
www.education.gov.au/higher-education-loan-program.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Dr Chalmers
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6518, with 323 signatures, concerning the processing times of Employer Nomination Scheme (subclass 186) visa applications. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Immigration provides our businesses with the skills they need, stimulates demand for goods and services, and increases our economic output. I am committed to maintaining strong borders and delivering an orderly and compassionate immigration strategy that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

The Australian Government released the Migration Strategy ("the Strategy") in December last year. A key objective of the Strategy is building stronger Australian communities by better planning the migration intake. This will better connect skilled migrants to Australia's skill needs, helping to reignite productivity growth, which will ensure rising living standards, business growth and better wages.

Reducing the number of on-hand visa applications, including in the subclass 186 caseload, has been a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs has been undertaking a range of measures to reduce the processing times for this type of application, and additional resources have been assigned to the caseload.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to government policy priorities, as outlined in Ministerial Direction 105. Under the Ministerial Direction, applications for the subclass 186 visa are prioritised where an occupation is to be carried out in a designated regional area. Priority is also given to applications in relation to healthcare or teaching occupations. Subclass 186 visa applications that are not made in relation to these priorities are given lower priority, and are generally processed in the order in which they were received.

Each application is unique, and is required to meet the eligibility criteria contained in Australia's migration legislation, before a visa can be granted. The time taken to process an application varies depending on a range of circumstances, such as the complexity of the application and whether additional checks and further assessment are required. Some delays in processing are experienced due to character and security checks, along with verification of an applicant's claims.

More detail regarding visa requirements, processing priorities for skilled visa applications and processing timeframes is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website. Currently, 90 per cent of subclass 186 applications are being processed within 6-12 months, depending on the chosen stream. The Department continues to process these applications efficiently, with the intention to further reduce the total number on-hand.

The signatories to this petition may be interested to know that the Government has increased the planning level for Employer Sponsored visa category from 36,825 visas in 2023-24 to 44,000 visas for the 2024-25 permanent Migration Program. This planning level builds on the expanded pathway to permanent residence introduced by the Government from November 2023. It will allow a greater proportion of temporary migrants to secure permanent residence in a timely manner through the Temporary Residence Transition Stream.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6518 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Parliamentary Standards
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the petition of 8 October 2024 requesting the introduction of truth in political advertising legislation.

On 18 November 2024, the Government introduced the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Electoral Communications) Bill 2024. This Bill would prohibit authorising paid electoral and referendum matter that is inaccurate and misleading to a material extent.

This Bill delivers on the recommendations of the Parliament's multi-partisan Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) to introduce legislation to govern truth in political advising, giving consideration to provisions in the Electoral Act 1985 (SA).

Electoral reform is complex and requires consultation across the Parliament. The Government is pursuing multi-partisan support for legislative reform, including this Bill, to strengthen our electoral system with improved transparency and accountability.
The Government will continue to engage with colleagues across the Parliament on the vital reforms in this Bill.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell (Petition No. 6530)
Animal Welfare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 October 2024 regarding a petition to allocate funding to veterinary hospitals and practices that treat wildlife patients—Petition Ministerial Referral (EN6532).

Wildlife carers, veterinarians and wildlife hospitals play an important role in caring for native wildlife. Wildlife rescue and care are primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments, though the Australian Government has provided support to the sector during the recent extreme and unprecedented 2019-20 Black Summer bushfires. Through the Saving Koalas Fund, the Australian Government is providing $19.5 million for koala hospital and koala health initiatives. These investments are primarily for the purpose of helping koalas, but also provide infrastructure and support to care for other native animals.

As you are aware, the Australian Government is also supporting actions that will lead to long-term recovery for threatened species listed under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. The Threatened Species Action Plan 2022-32 is helping to protect, manage and restore Australia's threatened species and important natural places. The Australian Government's $224.5 million Saving Native Species program is helping to implement this plan and look after our unique plants, animals and ecological communities.
Thank you again for bringing your concerns to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 regarding petition EN6536.

The petition asks the House of Representatives to create a register of people who make false allegations about domestic violence. I note the petition raises concerns about false allegations of domestic violence resulting in imprisonment, as well as impacting on people's finances and family law proceedings.

The Australian Government is firm in its view that domestic violence is unacceptable and cannot be tolerated, and is committed to ongoing improvements to the family law, courts and legal assistance systems to ensure that they support families to separate in a safe, child-centred, accessible and timely way.

Under Australia's federal system of government, States and Territories are responsible for the majority of laws related to domestic violence, including the making of domestic violence orders and criminal offences. Each jurisdiction manages its own criminal justice system, including criminal laws, policing, courts and corrections. The following information is therefore focussed on the family law system, noting that the Attorney-General's po1tfolio has responsibility for the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

Petition EN6536 raises concerns about the use of false allegations of domestic violence within the justice system. It is a role for the courts and, specifically, for family law court judges to consider the evidence presented, including allegations of domestic violence, and determine the weight it should be given. This is done on a case-by-case basis. The family law courts have broad powers to order costs against a party if false allegations or false denials are proven in court. In addition, a witness in proceedings who wilfully makes a statement significant to the proceedings which they know to be false, or do not believe to be true, may have committed the offence of perjury.

Where there is an allegation of perjury, the court may refer the allegation to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for investigation. The AFP is operationally independent of Government and has authority to make decisions about whether or not to investigate an alleged Commonwealth offence.

I also note the concerns raised in the petition regarding the misuse of systems. The Australian Government recognises this is a serious issue. The Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia has broad powers to manage the conduct of proceedings and can make orders to prevent misuse of court processes, including the power to summarily dismiss all or any part of proceedings that it considers frivolous, vexatious or an abuse of process.

At the National Cabinet meeting of 6 September 2024, the Government committed to immediately commence an audit of key Commonwealth government systems to identify areas where they are being weaponised by perpetrators of domestic violence. The audit will include the child support, social security and tax systems and will leverage existing reviews underway that seek to strengthen these systems.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Digital ID Legislation
Dear Ms Templeman
In response to petition number EN6548, please relay the below to the signatories of the petition.

A Digital ID is simply a voluntary online method of confirming your ID that does not require physical documents once it's set up. It works by verifying your existing ID documents such as a passport or driver license against the official record held by government.

Consultation on the legislative framework of Digital ID extends back to 2017. Three rounds of public consultation on the policy and draft legislation were held across 2020 and 2021. Consultation on the proposed draft Digital ID Bill as well as the associated legislative rules occurred between September and October 2023. Feedback received from the consultation resulted in a number of key changes to the Digital ID Bill.

The Digital ID Bill 2023 and the Digital ID (Transitional and Consequential Provisions) Bill 2023 were introduced into the Parliament on 30 November 2023 and referred to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 28 February 2024. The Senate Committee's report concluded that the Bills should be passed however, amendments were made to the Digital ID Bill to respond to the issues raised by the Committee's inquiry.
On 27 March 2024, the Bills passed the Senate and on 16 May 2024 the Bills passed the House of Representatives and became Acts of Parliament. The Acts commenced on 1 December 2024.
For more information on consultation conducted on the Bill, please visit:
digitalidsystem.gov.au/have-your-say.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Government Services, Senator Gallagher
Bahrain: Human Rights
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN6557 and its call for the release of Professor Abduljalil Al-Singace.
The Australian Government takes all allegations of human rights violations and arbitrary detention seriously. We are deeply concerned by the reports of ill-treatment of Professor Al- Singace.

The Australian Embassy in Riyadh is accredited to Bahrain and closely monitors the human rights situation there. The Embassy regularly makes representations on human rights to the Government of the Kingdom of Bahrain and engages in constructive bilateral dialogue on specific human rights issues, including freedom of speech, freedom of expression, and prisoner welfare.

We are also using our voice in international institutions and fora to call for the upholding of human rights in Bahrain. Australia has raised Bahrain's human rights record in the Human Rights Council. Our statement to the Universal Periodic Review Working Group in November 2022 expressed deep concern with reports of torture, enforced disappearance and abuse of detainees. It urged Bahrain to protect detainees against torture and other ill-treatment, uphold the rights to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly, end the ban on protests, and establish a moratorium on the death penalty with a view to its abolition.

The Australian Government will continue to advocate strongly in support of the human rights of the Bahraini people, including to call for an end to arbitrary detention and for the fair and humane treatment of all prisoners.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important manner.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
COVID-19: Response
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 3 November 2024 regarding the petition (EN6578) that requests an inquiry be held on the Australian Government's Response to COVID-19.
On 25 October 2024, the Government received the final report from the independent panel appointed to review the response to the COVID-19 pandemic (COVID-19 Response Inquiry).

The COVID-19 Response Inquiry reviewed the Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic to identify lessons learned and improve Australia's preparedness for future pandemics. The Inquiry consulted widely, receiving 2,201 public submissions representing a breadth of experiences and reflections across governments, business, community organisations, unions and everyday Australians. The Inquiry also held 27 roundtables with 300 individuals to test what worked well and what needs to change.

The report includes nine guiding recommendations that are aligned with nine pillars of a successful pandemic response. The report identifies 19 immediate actions for the next 12-18 months, and seven medium-term actions prior to the next national health emergency. In line with the report, the Government is delivering on its commitment to establish an independent Australian Centre for Disease Control (CDC). The Australian CDC will ensure Australia has a national organisation than brings together critical information and experts to deliver coherent, timely health advice to improve health outcomes for the Australian population. The Government will release a full response to the report in due course.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender Based Violence
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter of 4 November 2024 conveying petition number EN6581, which requests the Australian Parliament to recognise 16 September as 'Women, Life, Freedom' Day.

The Australian Government stands with the women and girls of Iran and Iranian human rights defenders in their ongoing fight for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I publicly condemned Iran's brutal crackdown of the Women, Life, Freedom protests sparked by the tragic death of Mahsa Jina Amini in September 2022, and supported calls by the Acting UN High Commissioner for Human Rights for a prompt, impartial and independent investigation into Ms Amini's death.

Since Ms Amini's death I have imposed sanctions against 200 Iranian individuals and entities, including those responsible for the oppression of women and girls. This includes Magnitsky-style sanctions I announced in December 2022 against Iran's Morality Police, the Basij Resistance Force, and six Iranian individuals involved in the crackdown, and further sanctions announced in September 2023 and 2024 to mark the anniversary of Ms Amini's death.

The Australian Government has advocated for sustained international pressure on Iran for its treatment of women and Girls, including by delivering statements at the UN General Assembly and Human Rights Council. Australia was at the forefront of efforts to remove Iran from the UN Commission on the Status of Women in December 2022 in response to Iran's actions to continuously undermine and increasingly suppress the human rights of women and girls including by using excessive force.

In April 2024, Australia co-sponsored a resolution to extend the mandates of the Special Rapporteur on the Human Rights Situation in Iran and the Independent Fact-Finding Mission, the responsible mechanisms for investigating human rights violations stemming from Iran's violent repression of the 2022 protests.

On 17 September 2024, I issued a joint statement with the US Secretary of State and Foreign Ministers of the UK, Canada and New Zealand on the second anniversary of Ms Amini's death. In the statement, we acknowledged the ongoing unity of the Women, Life, Freedom movement and called on the new Iranian Administration to fulfil its pledge to ease pressure on civil society in Iran. I also conveyed these messages directly with Iranian Foreign Minister Araghchi on 26 September 2024.

I have passed a copy of the petition to the co-chairs of the Australian Parliamentary Group on Population and Development (APGPD) for their information and consideration. As you know, the APGPD works across party lines to champion women's empowerment and break down gender discrimination.

Australia remains steadfast in our determination to work with the international community to hold Iran to account for its systemic oppression of women and girls and to advocate for the human rights of all Iranian people.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Cc. Ms Lisa Chesters MP, Federal Member for Bendigo, Co-Chair of Australian Parliamentary Group on Population Development
Senator Mehreen Faruqi, Senator for NSW, Co-Chair of Australian Parliamentary Group on Population Development
Dr Monique Ryan MP, Member for Kooyong, Co-Chair of Australian Parliamentary Group on Population Development
Young Australians
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 4 November 2024 regarding Petition EN6599 on a proposed National Youth Meet and Greet Day.

I acknowledge the issues raised in the petition, including the challenges faced by young people and the importance of including young people in government decision-making. The Australian Government is committed to creating opportunities for meaningful engagement with young people to ensure their views are reflected in the policies and programs that affect them.

As part of the Government's Youth Engagement Model, the Office for Youth engaged over 4,600 young people from across Australia in 2023 to develop Engage! A strategy to include young people in the decisions we make. This strategy, launched in March 2024, highlights 3 priority areas where we will recognise and listen to young people, empower young people to advocate, engage with and support government to work with young people.

Under Engage! the Government committed to an annual National Youth Forum where young people work together to present policy solutions to the Australian Government. The first National Youth Forum was held in March 2024 at the National Museum of Australia and was attended by more than 100 diverse young people from across Australia. Topics for the forum were based on the top 3 issues raised by young people during the National Youth Consultations in 2023: mental health, climate change, and cost of living.

Additionally, under the Youth Engagement Model the Government provides funding to the Australian Youth Affairs Coalition (AYAC) to advocate on behalf of and support young people. AYAC has successfully supported the establishment of a Parliamentary Friends of Young People Group co-convened by Mr Andrew Wilkie MP, Member for Clark, and Ms Rebekha Sharkie MP, Member for Mayo. This Friendship Group provides a non-partisan forum for Senators and Members to meet and interact with young people and youth-led organisations to discuss matters relating to areas of policy that affect young Australians.

The National Youth Meet and Greet Day had the opportunity to be presented and discussed at this Friendship Group and I will encourage AYAC to continue to support young people to advocate for this idea across the Parliament.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Youth, Dr Aly
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 November 2024 enclosing Petition EN6613, with 554 signatures, concerning Sri Lankan Tamil asylum seekers in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Australia is a multicultural nation where its first priority should be how we can focus on inclusion and bringing people together.

The previous Government left thousands of people, who had been subject to the 'Fast Track' process, in limbo for more than a decade. This was one aspect of the broken migration system the Albanese Government inherited.

The Government has focused on providing those who engage Australia's protection obligations a chance to continue their lives in Australia with certainty and security, and has provided these individuals with a permanent pathway through the Resolution of Status visa.

I am working through the remaining cohort with the Department of Home Affairs. Not everyone is in an identical situation—some individuals may have new protection claims relating to their country of origin, while others may have compelling or compassionate circumstances that provide a basis for them to remain in Australia.

I have asked my Department to refer people with new protection claims or those with other compelling and compassionate circumstances for consideration under Ministerial Intervention powers. Individuals who arrived in Australia as unaccompanied minors, and those who arrived before 2010, will be prioritised.
Further information regarding ministerial intervention processes, including how to make a request for intervention, is available on the Department's website.

I wish to assure the signatories to petition EN6613 that Australia does not return individuals to situations where it has been found they face persecution or a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life, or the application of the death penalty.

The signatories may also be interested to know the Immigration Assessment Authority (IAA), which was established in April 2015, was abolished on 14 October 2024 with the commencement of the new Administrative Review Tribunal (the Tribunal). Any cases still active with the IAA (i.e. cases not yet decided) on 14 October 2024 have been transferred to the Tribunal for continuation of review. The Tribunal has written to applicants whose cases were transferred confirming the transfer has taken place and providing them with a new case reference number. Further information is available at:
https://www.art.gov.au/immigration-assessment-authority.

The Government understands that it may be difficult for anyone to support themselves while their immigration matter is being resolved, if they cannot work and participate in the community. A Bridging visa is intended to allow an applicant to reside lawfully in the community while they resolve their immigration status.

The conditions that apply to an individual's Bridging visa are determined based on their individual circumstances. TPV and SHEV applicants who hold a valid Bridging visa generally have work and study rights, and may also be eligible to receive access to:
Medicare and the public health system;
education for school aged children;
assistance with finding employment if they have work rights;
translating and interpreting services; and
the Status Resolution Support Services (SRSS) Program, which can include financial assistance and accommodation.

Services Australia determines whether or not applicants are eligible for Medicare benefits. As part of the Medicare enrolment process, applicants need to demonstrate their current visa status. A visa holder can check their current visa details and conditions by using the Department's Visa Entitlement Verification Online system (VEVO).

While the Government is working through the Fast Track cohort, it also remains committed to delivering orderly and legal pathways to Australia through robust migration and humanitarian programs. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining Operation Sovereign Borders, including regional processing arrangements. Under this approach, anyone who attempts to travel to Australia by boat without a valid visa will be turned back to their point of departure, returned to their home country, or transferred to a regional processing country for assessment of their protection claims.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6613 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Mental Health
Thank you for your correspondence of 3 November 2024 regarding Petition Number EN6614 request to increase Medicare benefits for psychological sessions to 26 sessions per year for individuals.

I also note your recent correspondence of 3 June 2024 regarding a similar petition (number EN6102) to increase psychological sessions to a minimum of 20 sessions per year for individuals. A response to this correspondence was dispatched to you on 6 August 2024.

As previously advised, increasing individual psychological session numbers as part of a tiered model of treatment carries a high risk of further entrenching inequities. An independent evaluation by the University of Melbourne found that providing additional services to existing consumers limited the capacity of providers to offer treatment to new users, with many people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds and regional, rural and remote areas missing out.

Since the additional Better Access sessions ceased on 31 December 2022, 44,927 additional people entered the program and used the initial 10 Better Access individual treatment sessions in 2023, compared to 2022 figures. You can read the Australian Government's response to the Better Access evaluation at:
https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/2024-08/australian-government-response-to-the-better-access-evaluation.pdf.

Since my previous correspondence on 6 August 2024, I am pleased to add that the Department of Health and Aged Care has established the Better Access Industry Liaison Group (Liaison Group) which brings the sector together via 17 key stakeholder organisations including the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine and the Australian Indigenous Doctors Association.

The Liaison Group has been established to ensure there are no unintended consequences or patient access issues arising during, or as a result of, implementation of the changes to the Better Access to Psychiatrists, Psychologists and General Practitioners through the Medicare Benefits Schedule initiative as announced through the 2024-25 Budget.

The Government is also investing in complementary models of mental health care to ensure Australians get the right level of care for their level of need. In the 2024-25 Budget, the Government invested $361 million in the mental health and suicide prevention system. This includes:
$163.9 million for a new national early intervention service that anyone can access for free, whenever they need it
$29.9 million for an upgraded nationwide network of 61 Medicare Mental
Health Centres to offer free, walk-in access to mental health care professionals for adults with more complex mental health needs

$71.7 million to fund Primary Health Networks to work in partnership with general practices to commission mental health workers to offer wraparound care for people with high needs in between medical appointments
$7.1million to establish a new national peer workforce association will help to mobilise, professionalise and unlock the potential of this all-important workforce.
This investment shifts away from the one-size-fits-all approach and will relieve pressure on the Better Access initiative.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Rural and Regional Health Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 4 November 2024 regarding petition number EN6617.

The Australian Government acknowledges the unique challenges and disparities rural and remote communities face when accessing health care. These challenges faced by rural and remote communities can include attracting and retaining health professionals to provide local primary care services.

There is no one-size-fits-all solution to addressing health workforce shortages in rural and remote Australia. Standard solutions like traditional models of GP service delivery may not work in all communities. The primary issue for the rural health workforce in Australia is one of equitable distribution rather than undersupply. GP numbers in Australia increased at two and a half times the rate of population growth, however, the bulk of this growth has occurred in major capital cities and metropolitan areas.

The Government is committed to addressing these challenges to meet the needs of Australians in rural and remote areas by working to improve the capacity, quality and distribution of the health workforce.

The Mid-term Review of the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA), published on 24 October 2024, made 45 recommendations including recommendations to improve health equity and outcomes for Australians living in rural and remote communities. Recommendation 36 was that the importance of improving equitable access to health care services in rural and remote areas should be reflected in a new and dedicated Schedule in a future NHRA Agreement.
As part of discussions about the next NHRA Addendum, these recommendations, including Recommendation 36, are being carefully considered by governments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Migration: Family Reunification
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 enclosing petition EN6630, with 144 signatures, concerning the cost and processing times for Parent visas. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government acknowledges the important role family migration plays in delivering social outcomes for Australia and contributing to social cohesion by strengthening family and community bonds in Australia. The Family Stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members, including partners, children and parents, of Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens.

The number of places allocated to the permanent Parent program is decided annually as part of the permanent Migration Program planning process. The Government determines the number of places for the Migration Program following public consultations, and sets the program with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind.

The permanent Parent visa program within the Family Stream consists of Contributory and non-Contributory visa subclasses. For program year 2024-25 (commencing on 1 July 2024), 8,500 places have been allocated to the permanent Parent visa program. This is the same number of places allocated for program year 2023-24.

The Government is aware of concerns about processing times and the cost of permanent Parent visas. Processing times for permanent Parent visa applications are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places allocated to a program each year within the broader migration program and the level of demand. For a number of years, high volumes of permanent Parent visa application lodgements have exceeded annual migration planning levels, which has impacted processing times for permanent Parent visas.

Visa Application Charges (VAC) are taxes imposed on visa applicants, including applicants in the Family stream, and are set by Government in accordance with policy objectives. As general taxation, all revenue is returned to Government to provide services to the community.

VACs are subject to annual indexation, and a range of considerations are taken into account when setting them, including the Government's policy intentions and the size and composition of the Migration program. Parent migrants draw upon Government services over the course of their lifetime in Australia, and the VACs for Parent visas in most cases only partially offset the cost of Parent migrants to the budget.

In addition to the permanent Parent visa program, the Government facilitates short-term family reunification through temporary visas, which allow for a temporary stay in Australia, which can be utilised by parents of Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens:

The Sponsored Parent (Temporary) (subclass 870) visa (SPTV) allows parents of Australian sponsors to visit Australia for up to three or five years at one time, for a combined maximum stay of up to 10 years.

Visitor visas are available for the purposes of a short term stay in Australia, including family visits. Visitor visa policy also allows for parents of Australian citizens or permanent residents to be granted Visitor visas with visa validity periods greater than the standard 12 months.
Thank you for bring petition EN6630 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigrations and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your letter of 18 November 2024 concerning petition EN6645 to the House of Representatives to allow Psoriatic Arthritis to be included in the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).

The National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) determines eligibility based on functional impairment, not diagnosis. This means no condition, including Psoriatic Arthritis, can be automatically included in the NDIS.

Anyone with a disability is able to access the NDIS if they meet the requirements set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013, including age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements.

Generally, a person will be eligible for the NDIS if their impairment is, or is likely to be, permanent and causes a substantial reduction in their capacity to do one or more daily life activities, including moving around, communicating, socializing, learning, undertaking self-care, or self-management tasks.

Many participants have medical conditions they manage alongside impairments arising from their disability. In making decisions, the NDIA must consider the roles and responsibilities of mainstream service systems, such as health, in supporting people with disability and fulfilling universal service obligations to all Australians.

Australia's health system continues to be responsible for the diagnosis and clinical treatment of health conditions. This includes treatment of chronic health conditions, acute and post-acute care, and palliative care. Accordingly, people with impairments that are not eligible for the NDIS and require health related interventions, are more appropriately supported by the health system.
Further information about testing eligibility for the NDIS is available on the NDIS website at:
www.ndis.gov.au/applying-access-ndis.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention. I trust this information clarifies the matter.
Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
Freedom of Speech
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 18 November 2024 regarding Petition EN6661 which calls for the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2024 (the Bill) to be rejected.
On 24 November 2024, the Australian Government announced that it will not proceed with the Bill, given there is no clear pathway to legislate this proposal through the Senate.

The Bill was about looking under the hood of the digital platforms to verify how digital platforms already take actions to moderate content and hold big tech to account for their efforts to prevent and minimise the spread of harmful mis- and disinformation. This included:
addressing seriously harmful content with measures around the use of algorithms, bots, fake accounts, malicious deep fakes, advertising, and monetisation;
the publication of risk assessments, policies, and reports;
a data access scheme for independent researchers;
empowering users with complaints and dispute procedures to challenge the content moderation decisions of platforms; and,
measures to support media literacy.

The Bill did not include fines for everyday Australians posting on their social media accounts, and would not have required the removal of content unless it was disinformation involving inauthentic behaviour such as bots or troll farms.
Thank you for taking the time to write and I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Human Rights: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 regarding Petition EN6666 in relation to the introduction of legislation to protect and enshrine human rights.

The Australian Government is committed to promoting human rights to ensure that all Australians are able to participate fully in our democracy, our economy and our society. Human rights in Australia are recognised and protected through the Australian Constitution, the common law and a range of laws at the federal, state and territory levels.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus KC
Migration: Regional Visa Holders
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 enclosing Petition EN6687, with 280 signatures, concerning the processing of Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa applications. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Immigration provides our businesses with the skills they need, stimulates demand for goods and services, and increases our economic output. I am committed to maintaining strong borders and delivering an orderly and compassionate immigration strategy that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

The Australian Government released the Migration Strategy ("the Strategy") in December last year. A key objective of the Strategy is building stronger Australian communities by better planning the migration intake. This will better connect skilled migrants to Australia's skill needs, helping to reignite productivity growth, which will ensure rising living standards, business growth and better wages.

Reducing the number of on-hand visa applications, including in the subclass 191 caseload, has been a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs has been undertaking a range of measures to reduce the processing times for this type of application, and additional resources have been assigned to the caseload.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to government policy priorities, as outlined in Ministerial Direction 105. Under the Ministerial Direction, for applications which are not employer sponsored and in relation to an occupation to be carried out in a designated regional area, the highest priority is being afforded to those visa applications made in relation to healthcare or teaching occupations.
As subclass 191 visa applications are not made in relation to a specific occupation, they are given lower priority, and are generally processed in the order in which they were received.

Currently, 90 per cent of subclass 191 visas are processed within nine months, which is consistent with the processing times for other general skilled migration visa applications. The Department continues to process these applications efficiently, with the intention to further reduce the total number on-hand.

It should be noted that each application is unique and is required to meet the eligibility criteria contained in Australia's migration legislation, before a visa can be granted. The time taken to process an application varies depending on a range of circumstances, such as the complexity of the application and whether additional checks and further assessment are required. Some delays in processing are experienced due to character and security checks, along with verification of an applicant's claims.
More detail regarding visa requirements, processing priorities for skilled visa applications and processing timeframes is available on the Department's website.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6687 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Bangladesh
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence referring petition number EN6691 regarding violence against Hindus, other religious and indigenous communities in Bangladesh.

The Australian Government understands this is matter of great concern to the Bangladeshi community in Australia, and to many Australians with family, friends and connections in Bangladesh. I offer my deepest sympathies to the families and friends of all those who have lost their lives or been injured.

During the civil unrest in Bangladesh, I repeatedly called on all parties to cease violence, de-escalate the situation and respect universal human rights. The Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Tony Burke MP, also raised human rights concerns with members of Bangladesh's Interim Government during his visit to Bangladesh on 31 October and 1 November. Minister Burke also met representatives from Bangladesh's Hindu, Christian and Buddhist communities to hear their concerns.

Australia strongly supports the independent investigation into all alleged human rights violations in Bangladesh between 1 July and 15 August that is being conducted by the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR). The OHCHR has been tasked with establishing facts, identifying responsibilities, analysing root causes and providing recommendations on next steps. Its report will be completed by the end of the year.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Murray River
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 November 2024 about VIP—(Standing Committee on Petitions, Templeman MP)—Maintain a navigable water channel from Goolwa South Australia through to Mildura—Petition Ministerial Referral (EN6692).

Tourism, including activities that rely on having a navigable river, is an important part of our River Murray communities. As you have pointed out, the Murray Darling Basin Agreement (the Agreement), which has superseded the River Murray Waters Agreement of 1915, includes provisions for navigation.

The Agreement requires the state government nominated to operate the respective weir and lock, maintain immediately downstream of the lock, such depth of water sufficient for the navigation of vessels drawing 1.4 metres of water unless determined otherwise by the Murray Darling Basin Authority.

The Agreement further allows for dredging works upstream of the relevant weirs from time to time to support navigability. This is limited to occasions when the works have been approved in the respective work plans or during an emergency.
In other words, maintaining a navigable channel through the weir pool and immediately downstream is the responsibility of the respective state governments.

I understand that the current work plan for the operation and maintenance of the locks and weirs includes the maintenance of navigable depth immediately downstream but does not include dredging of the weir pool upstream of the weir.

I will raise the issue of boat navigation through weir pools with my Joint Government partners of the Murray Darling Basin Agreement at our next meeting. Regarding issues of navigation immediately downstream of the locks and weirs, I encourage you to reach out to the respective state agencies.

In South Australia, the Department for Infrastructure and Transport (DIT)—Marine Safety SA are the agency responsible for boat navigation. For concerns and reporting of hazards it is best to contact dit.marinesafety@sa.gov.au (marked to the attention of "Marine Safety & Compliance Unit").

In New South Wales, NSW Maritime are the agency responsible. They are aware of the hazards below Lock 7 and have a warning in place for that reach of the river (see NSW Maritime Marine Notice No. SO2430). If you would like to get in touch with them to discuss this further, please contact NSW Maritime by phone on 13 12 36.
Thank you again for bringing petition EN6692 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

p.span: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 14 May 2024 regarding petition PN0605 about the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners in China.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned that minorities in China, including Falun Gong practitioners, continue to be targeted on the basis of their beliefs. I have raised our concerns about freedom of belief directly with China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi, most recently in March this year. Representatives of my office and my department met Falun Gong community members in March to discuss human rights concerns and the detention of family members.

We are aware of the statement by twelve UN experts of 14 June 2021 on allegations of 'organ harvesting' targeting minorities in detention, including Falun Gong practitioners. The Government has expressed concern to China regarding allegations of organ trafficking on a number of occasions. The Australian Government will continue to examine closely allegations of organ trafficking in China and, as appropriate, raise the issue with China.

The Australian Government is committed to preventing organ trafficking more broadly and will continue to monitor transplantation practices of other countries and regularly review available evidence as new reports are published.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Australia Post
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 4 November 2024 regarding a petition (PN0623) requesting Australia Post to retain the Spit Junction Post Office in Mosman, New South Wales. I apologise for the delay in responding but wanted to ensure this response provided relevant information to assist you.

I acknowledge the concerns raised in the petition about the closure of the Post Office and the impact this may have on residents, in particular the elderly and people with limited mobility being able to access postal and other services in the area.

Australia Post is required to perform its functions consistent with sound commercial practice and meet a range of performance standards outlined in the Australian Postal Corporation (Performance Standards) Regulations 2019. Under the Performance Standards Regulations, Australia Post is required to maintain 4,000 post offices, including 2,500 in non-metropolitan locations. As at 30 June 2024, Australia Post maintained 4,198 retail outlets, which exceeded the regulatory requirement of 4,000.

The Australian Government has not reduced the minimum number of post offices that Australia Post must maintain. Post Office closures within regulatory requirements are a decision for Australia Post, and the Government expects that any closures are operationally necessary and will be done in consultation with affected stakeholders.

Australia Post's day to day operations are the responsibility of its board and management. By law, it is legally and financially separate from the Government and does not receive financial support from the Government.
Australia Post has advised that the Spit Junction Post Office experienced significant financial losses, driven by a continued decline in customers, making it financially unviable.

The community can access postal services at the nearby Mosman Post Office which is less than one kilometre away and there are 10 alternative outlets within five kilometres of the Spit Junction Post Office. In addition, Australia Post has established nearby a new self-service hub with 24/7 parcel lockers, Post Office Boxes and a vending machine selling postal products.
The Government will continue to work with Australia Post, licensees and communities so that services meet the needs of modern Australia, consistent with existing regulatory requirements.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN5547, with 259 signatures, concerning Visa 309 Processing time in Amman Office. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I acknowledge the concerns expressed in the petition regarding processing times for Partner visa applications assessed in the Department of Home Affairs' office in Amman. I also note that similar concerns regarding Partner visa processing times were raised in earlier Petitions presented to the Standing Committee on Petitions, albeit not specific to the Amman or other offshore visa processing offices.

The Department aims to process all Partner visa application as quickly as is practicable. Actual processing timeframes can vary depending on a number of factors that may include, but are not limited to, the quality and completeness of applications, the applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity involved in assessing relationship, character, health and security requirements.

Concerning Partner visa processing at the Department's offshore offices, I can advise that the Department manages the allocation of resources to deliver the Family program in line with the planning levels and priorities set by the Government.

Since 2021-22, the Partner visa program has operated under a fully global processing model, allowing better distribution of the caseload across various processing locations in and outside Australia. The model ensures a greater degree of consistency in visa processing and program delivery, and allows for more agile responses to external impacts on the program, such as COVID-19 and other regional crisis.

In addition, the model allows decision ready applications to be easily identified and finalised. However, complex cases will continue to require greater scrutiny and longer times to finalise, and processing times may still vary between processing locations.

I acknowledge that applicants may be separated from their partners for extended periods while awaiting a decision on their Partner visa application. If a specific case is needing more urgent consideration, the Department has a Partner Visa Enquiry Form which applicants can access via the Department's website to request priortisation on compassionate and compelling grounds. See:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/departmental-forms/online-forms/partner-processing-enquiry-form.

Requests for priority consideration from Partner visa applicants are extremely common, including due to the ongoing security, political and economic instability in many areas of the Middle East region. As a result, to be considered for priority processing, the nature of circumstances presented as compassionate needs to be an exception to the daily circumstances faced by the majority of Partner applicants.
Thank you for bringing petition EN5547 to my attention. I trust the above information is useful.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5580.

I welcome the public's views on Australia's tax system and value the interest the public takes in public policy. These representations are valuable and inform considerations of the policy issues to which they relate.

The GST applies to most goods and services, with only a limited number of exemptions in areas such as health and education. The revenue from the GST, though levied by the Commonwealth Government, is provided to the states and territories. This provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community.

Under the Commonwealth legislation and the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations, any change to the application of GST, such as the application of GST to electricity, would require the unanimous support of the states and territories.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5640 to make it illegal for all business to not accept cash.

The Government understands the important role cash still plays in our payments system and supports Australians having continued access to cash. Cash is an important payment method for some people, including those unable to use digital payments and those in regional areas, and plays a vital role in their inclusion in the wider economy. Cash is still accepted by up to 94 per cent of merchants as a means of payment, is used as a store of value, and supports payment system resilience during digital payment outages.

On 7 June 2023, the Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System was released. It details the Government's priorities and objectives in relation to payments and includes a commitment to continued cash access for Australians. You can find the plan at: www.treasury.gov.au/publication/p2023-404960.

On 18 November 2024, the Government announced that it will introduce a mandate requiring businesses to accept cash when selling essential items, with appropriate exemptions for small businesses. Mandating cash for essential purchases, such as groceries and fuel, means those who rely on cash will not be left behind.

On 20 December 2024, a consultation paper was issued to seek feedback on which businesses supplying essential goods and services should be covered by the mandate. The consultation will consider the needs of those who rely on cash, including people in regional areas and those unable to use digital payments. It will also consider whether further steps are required to ensure the long-term and sustainable distribution of cash to enable adequate access. The paper is available at:
www.treasury.gov.au/consultation/c2024-604832.
The final details of the mandate will be announced in 2025, and subject to outcomes from consultation, the mandate would commence from 1 January 2026.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

p.span: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5674.
I recognise the value that exercise physiology services can provide to members of the community to support their wellbeing.

The goods and services tax (GST) applies broadly to goods and services, with only a limited number of exemptions in areas such as health and education. Limiting the number of exemptions helps to minimise complexity in the GST system.

The revenue from GST, though levied by the Commonwealth Government, is provided to the states and territories. This provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community.

Under Commonwealth legislation and the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations, changing the application of GST, such as to exercise physiology services, would require the unanimous support of the states and territories.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

p.span: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5701.
I recognise the value that exercise physiology services can provide to members of the community to support their wellbeing.

The goods and services tax (GST) applies broadly to goods and services, with only a limited number of exemptions in areas such as health and education. Limiting the number of exemptions helps to minimise complexity in the GST system.

The revenue from GST, though levied by the Commonwealth Government, is provided to the states and territories. This provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community.

Under Commonwealth legislation and the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations, changing the application of GST, such as to exercise physiology services, would require the unanimous support of the states and territories.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN5750, with 105 signatures, concerning long processing times for offshore Partner visa. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I acknowledge the concerns expressed in the petition regarding processing times for Partner visa applications assessed in the Department of Home Affairs' office in Amman. I also note that similar concerns regarding Partner visa processing times were raised in an earlier Petition, 'Visa 309 Processing time in Amman Office (EN5547)'.

The Department aims to process all Partner visa applications as quickly as is practicable. Actual processing timeframes can vary depending on a number of factors that may include, but are not limited to, the quality and completeness of applications, the applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity involved in assessing relationship, character, health and security requirements.

Concerning Partner visa processing at the Department's offshore offices, I can advise that the Department manages the allocation of resources to deliver the Family program in line with the planning levels and priorities set by the Government.

Since 2021-22, the Partner visa program has operated under a fully global processing model, allowing better distribution of the caseload across various processing locations in and outside Australia. The model ensures a greater degree of consistency in visa processing and program delivery, and allows for more agile responses to external impacts on the program, such as COVID-19 and regional crisis.

In addition, the model allows decision ready applications to be easily identified and finalised. However, complex cases will continue to require greater scrutiny and longer times to finalise, and processing times may still vary between processing locations.

I acknowledge that applicants may be separated from their partners for extended periods while awaiting a decision on their Partner visa application. If a specific case is needing more urgent consideration, the Department has a Partner Visa Enquiry Form which applicants can access via the Department's website to request prioritisation on compassionate and compelling grounds at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/departmental-forms/online-forms/partner-processing-enquiry-form.

Requests for priority consideration from Partner visa applicants are extremely common, including due to the ongoing security, political and economic instability in many areas of the Middle East region. As a result, to be considered for priority processing, the nature of circumstances presented as compassionate needs to be an exception to the daily circumstances faced by the majority of Partner applicants.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5750 to my attention. I trust the above information is useful.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke

subdebateinfo.title: Health Care: Goods and Services Tax

p.span: Health Care: Goods and Services Tax
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5850.
I recognise the value that exercise physiology services can provide to members of the community to support their wellbeing.

The goods and services tax (GST) applies broadly to goods and services, with only a limited number of exemptions in areas such as health and education. Limiting the number of exemptions helps to minimise complexity in the GST system.

The revenue from GST, though levied by the Commonwealth Government, is provided to the states and territories. This provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services to the community.

Under Commonwealth legislation and the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations, changing the application of GST, such as to exercise physiology services, would require the unanimous support of the states and territories.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5960.

The Government understands the important role cash still plays in our payments system and supports Australians having continued access to cash. Cash is an important payment method for some people, including those unable to use digital payments and those in regional areas, and plays a vital role in their inclusion in the wider economy. Cash is still accepted by up to 94 per cent of merchants as a means of payment, is used as a store of value, and supports payment system resilience during digital payment outages.

On 7 June 2023, the Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System was released. It details the Government's priorities and objectives in relation to payments and includes a commitment to continued cash access for Australians. You can find the plan at: www.treasury.gov.au/publication/p2023-404960.

On 18 November 2024, the Government announced that it will introduce a mandate requiring businesses to accept cash when selling essential items, with appropriate exemptions for small businesses. Mandating cash for essential purchases, such as groceries and fuel, means those who rely on cash will not be left behind.

On 20 December 2024, a consultation paper was issued to seek feedback on which businesses supplying essential goods and services should be covered by the mandate. The consultation will consider the needs of those who rely on cash, including people in regional areas and those unable to use digital payments. It will also consider whether further steps are required to ensure the long-term and sustainable distribution of cash to enable adequate access. The paper is available at:
www.treasury.gov.au/consultation/c2024-604832.
The final details of the mandate will be announced in 2025, and subject to outcomes from consultation, the mandate would commence from 1 January 2026.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 June 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP, enclosing Petition EN6116, with 59 signatures, concerning prioritising onshore Employer Nomination Scheme (subclass 186), Temporary Residence Transition stream applicants. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Ministerial Direction No. 105 prioritises applications for certain skilled visa subclasses that count towards the migration program, of which the Employer Nomination Scheme (subclass 186), Temporary Residence Transition (TRT) stream applies. This visa stream allows skilled workers who are nominated by their employer, to live and work in Australia permanently.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6116 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
International Students
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 June 2024 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Andrew Giles MP enclosing Petition EN6198, with 21,298 signatures, concerning the reduction of the maximum eligible age in the Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa (TGV). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Migration Strategy, released on 11 December 2023, outlined the Australian Government's vision for getting migration working for the nation and building a migration system that delivers for workers, businesses and all Australians. It outlined a suite of broader structural reforms aimed to ensure that our most highly skilled international graduates drive long term prosperity by transitioning to permanent visas as soon as possible. Key objectives of the Migration Strategy are to build stronger communities and reduce migrant worker exploitation by reducing the number of migrants who are permanently temporary.

Lowering the age eligibility from 50 to 35 years or under for the TGV supports the wider objective of reducing 'permanent temporariness' and repositions the visa as a visa for early career professionals to gain valuable work experience. This change applied from 1 July 2024.

I am pleased to advise that the postgraduate research sector was excluded from the age eligibility reforms, meaning that Masters by Research and PhD graduates can continue to apply for a TGV if they are under 50 years of age. This concession recognises the contribution these graduates make to Australia's research and innovation capabilities and the Australian workforce. The Government is not currently considering reducing eligibility requirements for other university graduates given the alternate visa pathways available.
Further information on the 1 July 2024 changes to the TGV program, including the age reduction, is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary-graduate-485/changes.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6198 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Israel
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 12 August 2024 regarding petition number EN6288 concerning arrest warrants issued by the International Criminal Court (ICC), expelling the Israeli Ambassador and ceasing all export permits for weapons to Israel.
I appreciate you giving me the opportunity to explain how Australia has been contributing to global efforts to end this war.

Many Australians are understandably traumatised by the past year in the Middle East. Every day we see more unbearable scenes. The terrorist attack by Hamas on October 7, 2023: the worst loss of Jewish life in a single day since the Holocaust, and almost 100 hostages still held. And in Israel's response: 46,000 Palestinians killed—including more than 13,000 children. Almost two million Palestinians facing starvation.

While this conflict might be far away, it has been close to many in Australia. Some have lost family—or have loved ones in danger. On our own, Australia has few ways to move the dial in the Middle East. That's why we have been so focused on partnering with other countries that also want to end this war, deliver lifesaving aid, and uphold international law. It's only by being active in the international community that we can build momentum for peace.

Australia welcomes the announcement of a ceasefire and hostage agreement in Gaza after 15 months of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life. Australia has consistently been part of the international call for a ceasefire and release of hostages. It is more than a year since Australia voted for a ceasefire with 152 other countries at the United Nations General Assembly. As the conflict spread to Lebanon, we called for a ceasefire alongside dozens of others including the European Union and regional leaders Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates and Qatar.

As well as our co-ordinated calls for ceasefire and the release of hostages, we act in concert with other donors to provide lifesaving aid. Australia has committed more than $90 million in humanitarian assistance to support civilians impacted by conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon. We have also doubled our annual funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.

Australia works with Canada, New Zealand and other supporters of international law, including by backing the independence of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) and the ICC. The Netanyahu Government must comply with the ICJ's binding orders, including enabling the provision of basic services and enabling humanitarian assistance at scale. Concerning the ICC's decision to issue arrest warrants, the Government has been clear that Australia will consistently with its obligations under international law.

International law includes the UN Charter that allows countries to defend themselves—and the Geneva Conventions that protect civilians during wars. Palestinian civilians cannot pay the price of defeating Hamas.

In pressing for change, we consider the full range of tools we have available—diplomacy and dialogue, working in coalitions, multilateral forums, legislation, public statements. Sanctions are not our only choice in sending other countries a message, and they are rarely our first choice.

When Australia does apply sanctions, we co-ordinate with partners. That's what makes them effective. We joined a large number of countries in condemning and sanctioning Hamas, Hizballah and others for their terrorism. Just as we have partnered in sanctioning Israeli extremist settlers for their violence against Palestinians in the West Bank.

Australia maintains diplomatic relations with many countries because it is in our national interests to do so, even where we do not agree with everything those countries do. More than 160 countries maintain diplomatic relations with Israel, and we have been using our diplomatic ties to press Israel to adhere to international law, to coordinate consular assistance for Australians and their families wanting to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

Regarding Australians serving with the IDF, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not track the movements of Australians overseas. Under the Criminal Code Act 1995, it is an offence for Australians to engage in hostile activities overseas, unless serving in or with the armed forces of a foreign country. This legislation discourages Australians from fighting in overseas conflicts and endangering their lives and the lives of others. The Government encourages all Australians who seek to serve with the armed forces of a foreign country to carefully consider their legal obligations, and ensure their conduct does not constitute a criminal offence.

All-or-nothing demands do nothing to end the Middle East cycle of violence. That can only happen when the promise of two states is fulfilled—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.

Right now, this seems a distant prospect. It is bitterly opposed by Hamas, who seek to end the Jewish state. It is also not supported by many in the Netanyahu Government. But Palestinians have a right to self-determination, and Israel's own long-term security requires a two-state solution. We will continue working with the international community to press toward this goal.

In May 2024, Australia was one of 143 countries to vote in support of Palestinian aspirations for full membership of the UN -where I also called for a timeline for the international declaration of Palestinian statehood. No previous Australian government has taken these steps.

I understand Australians have wanted their government to make this war end. But this isn't Vietnam or Iraq—Australia is not contributing to the war. Nor have we supplied weapons for it. There is a big difference between Australia wanting to end this war—and being able to do it on our own.

The ceasefire and hostage agreement is a constructive step towards peace and stability in the region. It must mark the beginning of a new chapter for the Israeli and Palestinian people. We are urging all parties to respect its terms and safeguard a lasting peace, including ensuring the immediate release of all hostages and unimpeded and sustained increases in humanitarian assistance to all parts of Gaza.

Australia will continue working with the international community towards a two-state solution—a Palestinian state and the State of Israel, living side by side in peace and security within internationally recognised borders.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Taxation: Alcohol
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN6504 on alcohol excise tax. I note the petitioner's comments on alcohol taxation, and his specific suggestion to freeze the rate of excise.

Biannual indexation in accordance with the Consumer Price Index is a longstanding feature of the alcohol tax system. It ensures that alcohol excise amounts keep pace with inflation and that the tax component of alcoholic beverages remains broadly stable as a proportion of their total price. Without biannual indexation, the real value of alcohol excise would fall over time as alcohol prices rise in line with inflation.

Consistent with the Australian Government's National Drug Strategy for 2017-2026, excise is imposed on alcohol to help address the social and economic costs associated with excessive alcohol consumption. Revenue from excise, including alcohol excise, goes to fund essential services of benefit to the whole community, such as health and education.

The Government continually monitors the adequacy of all tax settings, current settings balance a variety of policy objectives such as health, industry support, control of illicit goods, consumer choice, and collecting revenue for essential services.
